Former Fed chief Alan Greenspan admitted he had been "partially wrong" in his hands-off approach towards the banking industry. The credit crunch had left him in a state of "shocked disbelief," he admitted before a congressional committee.

Goldman Sachs said it was to cut one-in-10 of its global workforce, likely to lead to 600 job losses in London.

The grisly conditions facing UK retailers were underlined when DSG, which operates Currys and PC World, revealed a big drop in sales of TVs and computers.

Daimler, maker of Mercedes cars, issued its second profits warning this year after third-quarter earnings plunged by two-thirds.

Thousands of workers at the manufacturing firm JCB voted to accept a pay cut of £50 a week to prevent the loss of 350 jobs.

The stricken US bank Wachovia reported the biggest quarterly loss of any bank since the onset of the credit crunch, with a deficit of $24bn - more than the total price being paid for the North Carolina lender by its rival Wells Fargo.

Pakistan sought emergency bail-out funds from the IMF

The Bank of England governor Mervyn King hinted at fresh interest rate cuts admitted "it now seems likely that the UK economy is entering a recession" in a speech to business leaders in Leeds.

Gordon Brown told MPs that if the government had not acted to stabilise the banking system, Britain's financial difficulties would have been "even more severe".

China warned the financial crisis was damaging its economic growth.

Mortgage lending slumped by 10% in September to its lowest level for more than three-and-a-half years.

Details emerged that Dutch savings bank ING was to get a €10bn (£7.7bn) capital injection from the Netherlands authorities.

Alistair Darling said the government would inject billions into the public sector to boost the economy, bringing forward large construction projects. However, it was reported that Britain's most expensive road improvement programme, the £5bn upgrade of the M25, was struggling to raise finance.

The Observer reported that the recession will hit people in finance and leisure, with London and the south bearing the brunt.

The Guardian reflected on the week in which global catastrophe was averted.

Lord Adair Turner, the Financial Service Authority chairman, told the Guardian that the days of soft-touch regulation were over, warning the City that higher-paid regulators would ask tougher questions in the wake of the credit crisis.

The Guardian learned that workers at Wall Street's top banks were to receive pay deals worth more than $70bn (£40bn), a substantial proportion of which is expected to be paid in discretionary bonuses, despite the global financial crisis.

The Dow Jones fell again but the FTSE closed up 201 points at 4063 - a 5.2% gain.

Labour saw its lead over the Tories on economic competence rise on the day in which David Cameron accused Gordon Brown of presiding over a "complete and utter failure" of economic policy.

The Dow Jones industrial Average shook off a mood of despondency to make strong gains, jumping by 401 points to 8979. Earlier, Japan's Nikkei suffered its worst fall since 1987 and the FTSE 100 index slumped by 218 points to 3861.

The Bank of England announced new rules intended to bring an end to the paralysis which has gripped the money markets.

An EU summit ended in Brussels with a clear message that there was no time to lose in coming up with concerted action to tackle the financial emergency.

In Switzerland, UBS received a capital injection from the government, while Credit Suisse raised money from private investors and a sovereign wealth fund.

In America, Citigroup suffered its fourth consecutive quarterly loss after taking hits of more than $13bn to cover liabilities arising from the credit crunch.

Opec called an emergency meeting in Vienna as the oil price fell to less than half the $147 it traded at in July.

The FTSE suffered its fifth biggest fall in history, closing down 7.16% at 4079.5 - a 315-point fall - more than wiping out all of Tuesday's gains. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones industrial average dropped by 7.8%.

US banks JP Morgan and Wells Fargo reported big falls in profits, and retail sales in the US suffered their biggest fall in three years, with the decline in car sales hitting 3.8%.

Iceland rushed to stave off economic ruin by slashing interest rates by 3.5% and pursuing talks with Russia over the possibility of a multibillion euro loan.

Shares in Asia, London and the rest of Europe rallied for a second day as the financial world waited for America to follow Britain's lead and partially nationalise its banks.

The Icelandic stock exchange resumed trading for the first time since last Wednesday, but six financial stocks remained suspended. The stockmarket plummeted 76% after the open.

Afternoon: Meetings between the US government and the heads of major banks were held in Washington.

RBS, which will get £20bn from the taxpayer, announces chief executive Sir Fred Goodwin and chairman Sir Tom McKillop are stepping down.

In Iceland, the authorities edge closer to a deal to repay savers, but have no plans to reimburse charities and councils. Meanwhile, UK magnate Sir Philip Green is looking into opportunities provided by the crisis in Reykjavik.

The 15 members of the eurozone, led by Germany and France, unveil large, coordinated plans along British lines to provide their banks with capital funding.

The prospect of governments pumping vast sums into banks on both sides of the Atlantic sends stocks soaring. The FTSE 100 closes 325 points higher at 4256.9, a rise of 8.3%.

The Dow Jones rockets by 936 points to 9387, its biggest one-day gain by points. It closes up 11%, the largest daily jump in percentage terms since 1933.

Sunday October 12

Gordon Brown travels to Paris where European officials are desperate to prevent a continent-wide meltdown in the banking sector. He succeeds in persuading the EU's core countries to adopt a plan along the lines of his £500bn banking system bail-out.

Lloyds TSB considers renegotiating the terms of its takeover of HBOS.

Saturday October 11

Alistair Darling attends meetings in Washington with the G7 finance ministers and the IMF. The G7 comes up with a five-point plan, which includes spending billions of taxpayers' money to rebuild the global banking system and reopen the flow of credit.

The head of the IMF, Dominique Strauss-Kahn tells a Washington meeting: "Intensifying solvency concerns about a number of the largest US-based and European financial institutions have pushed the global financial system to the brink of systemic meltdown."

Tories claim that councils "could lose £1bn" because of the collapse of Icelandic banks.

Gordon Brown goes on tour to explain the bank bail-out, with a podcast and regional tour to explain the government's £500bn banking rescue package to the public.

Not content with lese-majeste laws to protect the revered monarchy that are among the world's most draconian, Thailand is to build a wall around the kingdom to keep out detractors.

But the barrier will be virtual, a national internet firewall to block websites deemed insulting to the throne of King Bhumibol Adulyadej, who at 80 is the world's longest serving monarch.

For the princely sum of almost £9m the Thai information ministry will shield the king and his adoring subjects from the sleights – real or perceived – of those who mock online.

Thailand's government, locked in a bitter struggle with staunchly royalist demonstrators who have been on the streets for months, has been accused of harbouring republican tendencies and being hostile to the monarchy.

It refutes the charge, but the move to construct the firewall appears to be the result of pressure from the powerful military and its demand that criticism of the monarchy be stamped out.

The firewall will also give Thailand's bureaucrats the power to block other websites it labels inappropriate, like those run by perceived terrorist groups or showing pornography. But the first target will up to 1,000 websites suspected of carrying material regarded as offensive to the king.

Last year the government, which was appointed by the military after a coup in 2006, blocked the YouTube website for weeks after its parent company, Google, refused to take down a posting.

The 44-second clip showed a picture of the Thai king with a pair of women's feet suspended above his head. In Thai culture feet are regarded as dirty and the lowest part of the body.

Thailand's lese-majeste laws are harsh by any standard, promising 15 years imprisonment for anyone who "insults, defames or threatens" the royal family.

But the law allows anyone to make an accusation against anyone else, with the result that it is often abused to ensnare rivals.

The Thai prime minister, Somchai Wongsawat, has ordered police to be especially vigilant and special branch are monitoring community radio stations suspected of airing lese majeste content.

A number of people have been killed after overnight looting and panic gripped a Congolese town besieged by a rebel army, according to reports today.

UN radio said nine people were shot amid gunfire and looting in Goma, in the east of the Democratic Republic of Congo on the border with Rwanda.

Rebels loyal to the Tutsi warlord Laurent Nkunda closed in on Goma yesterday before declaring a ceasefire near its outskirts.

"Everybody's afraid of the wars. They are fearing what will happen next," a Goma resident, Tawite Anthony, told the BBC.

A BBC reporter, Thomas Fessy, said he saw a body with bullet wounds after shooting overnight when shops were looted by soldiers.

The UN peacekeeping force, Monuc, was preparing today to send reinforcements to the town, an important trading centre on the Congo-Rwanda border.

The fighting has sent tens of thousands of civilians running for their lives in North Kivu province, where aid workers say two years of violence has forced nearly 1 million people from their homes despite the end of Congo's broader 1998-2003 war.

A Reuters reporter saw Congolese army (FARDC) soldiers patrolling the streets, arresting drunken comrades and looters.

They detained one soldier whom they accused of killing the owner of a restaurant, whose body lay nearby.

Colonel Jonas Padiri of FARDC said he and his men had entered Goma to stop the looting.

Padiri said five people were killed overnight. UN-backed Radio Okapi said nine people were killed and three women raped.

Many of Goma's Tutsi residents fled across the border to the Rwandan town of Gisenyi, fearing reprisals.

"All the Tutsis have crossed. People were not feeling safe," John Kanyoni, a Tutsi businessman and mineral dealer, said by phone from Gisenyi.

Nkunda's men have already captured several key towns near Goma in North Kivu province and raised fears of a return to full scale war in Congo.

The national army has been routed and troops were reported to be fleeing Goma yesterday before the ceasefire. Tension between Congo and Rwanda, which it accuses of supporting Nkunda, also increased sharply, as they traded accusations yesterday over cross-border artillery attacks.

The US said while Rwanda was not directly involved in the fighting, its territory was being used to support rebels.

Congo's previous wars, between 1997 and 2003, which sucked in several neighbouring countries, caused the greatest loss of life anywhere since the second world war, with more than five million dying mainly from hunger and illness.

Since then the mineral-rich east region has remained restive, despite a peace agreement signed by all main rebel groups in January this year.

Nkunda, who is though to have 5,000 fighters in his National Congress for the Defence of the People (CNDP), claims to be protecting the minority Tutsi population in the east from Hutu militias linked to the 1994 Rwandan genocide.

Despite signing the deal, he refuses to disarm, accusing government forces of breaking the ceasefire and collaborating with Hutu rebels.

Nkunda said today he wanted direct negotiations with the government about security and his objections to a $5bn (£3bn) deal that gives China access to the region's mineral resources.

He told the Associated Press that he turned down a government offer of $2.5m to stop fighting because he could not abandon his mission to protect Congo's people.

Human Rights Watch says it has documented summary executions, torture and rape committed by soldiers under Nkunda's command in 2002 and 2004.

Struggles for Congo's mineral wealth have long been part of the country's wars.

A UN investigation on the illegal exploitation of natural resources in Congo found that the conflict in the country had become mainly about "access, control and trade" of five key mineral resources: diamonds, copper, cobalt, gold and coltan, a metallic ore that provides materials for mobile phones and laptops.

Exploitation of Congo's natural resources by foreign armies was "systematic and systemic," and the Ugandan and Rwandan leaders in particular had turned their soldiers into "armies of business". The UN panel estimated that Rwanda's army made at least $250m in 18 months by selling coltan.

THE QUESTION

What's so special about North Ronaldsay mutton?

Where do we start? These rare Orkney sheep live wild on the rocky shore of the north Atlantic, munching on seaweed. They have evolved to exist almost entirely on this diet, because a dry-stone wall has confined them to the shoreline since 1832. They venture out to graze at low tide, and ruminate at high tide.

The breed is ancient - about 5,000 years old - and still exists in its pure form on North Ronaldsay, where it outnumbers the human inhabitants of the island by about 50 to one. Each October, around 300 mature sheep are caught when the tide is out and the moon is up. Many of the carcasses are spirited away to London restaurants.

Enough about the sheep - what about the meat? The mutton is lean and rich in iodine (thanks to the seaweed diet), and is said to taste rich and gamey. We can't confirm this, as the 'mutton run' is still in progress, and the meat won't reach us until tomorrow. But as a unique local product, it should surely be celebrated.

This has been an odd campaign at times: great expectations about this being the final battle for Gordon Brown's career came crashing down with the stock markets.

As share prices fell, Brown's personal valuation rose, while in inverse proportion, the heat and edge in the campaign has dissipated.

This has left the parties and pundits picking for bones during an often-muted campaign, but one issue has regularly surfaced: the capacities of the leading candidates.

Despite the often artful campaign management by Labour and the SNP, Lindsay Roy, the non-politician chosen by Labour, and Peter Grant, the Fife council leader running for the nationalists, have both been tested.

Both have had slips, some potentially serious. Neither seems entirely at ease with the intense pressure of such a pivotal campaign.

With byelection day just a week away, the four leading candidates will stage their last television debate on STV tonight. A consensus is emerging: Roy is inexperienced, ill-prepared but committed and keen; Grant is clearly experienced, and obviously able, but appears reluctant to leave Fife for London.

The first STV head-to-head between Roy and Grant five weeks ago was a "car crash" for Roy, said one experienced observer. Labour insiders acknowledge he was ill-prepared. Roy, agreed to be a gifted headmaster who now runs Gordon Brown's old high school in Kirkcaldy, stumbled through his first answers.

The interviews were prerecorded. His alarmed minder cried foul, claimed Roy's earpiece wasn't working and demanded a second take. Still Roy went off script and rambled. The SNP were delighted when Roy said Brown's failure to call an election last year was a "mistake" – their first major point in the "gaffe game" both sides play.

Another gaffe-ometer point for the nationalists came when they uncovered a letter Roy had sent to an SNP councillor, subtly complaining about Labour education spending cuts in his old school's budget of nearly £140,000, before Labour lost control of Fife to the current SNP-Lib Dem coalition.
He's more practised now, less fazed by media questioning, and Labour has sent every household in Glenrothes a glossy mini-magazine with photos of Roy's RAF pilot father and mother, a second world war nurse, and his wedding photo – a wee Mills and Boon scrapbook for every home. Grant too has fumbled, and is now nicknamed "Homesick" by Labour. Earlier this week, he told the Telegraph's Scottish politics reporter that he only wanted to go to Westminster for five years, adding: "I don't want to have to spend any more time down there than I have to. I would be homesick after more than that."

He has been unsettled by challenges over steep rises imposed by his council in home help charges for the elderly - up from £4 a week to £11 an hour for some, and a new £51 charge for emergency alarms – and over the impact of the SNP's plans to replace council tax with a local income tax.
While the SNP insists that Grant's SNP-Lib Dem coalition has hired more teachers, extended free home care for more pensioners and frozen council tax, Grant has been harassed at public meetings by disability rights campaigners over homecare charges.

And as this blog reported earlier, Grant's coalition with the Lib Dems has been put under immense strain by SNP campaigning claims about local policy, particularly an apparent guarantee of council tax cuts to 2011 and free school meals for all under-eights – promises being challenged by his Lib Dem partners.

It is difficult to escape the impression sometimes that Grant, a mild-mannered, gentle man, would much rather be somewhere else.

As for Roy, tonight's studio debate will be another very public test of his nerve and his new career as politician – each candidate gets to question the others. This is where the headteacher faces his employer. Who will eventually feel like a school kid again?

1) Mexican grand prix, 1964

To this day, John Surtees remains the only man to have won championships on both two and four wheels, and this was the race that he secured his formula one drivers' crown. But he did it by a whisker — after 10 races, the championship was decided in the very last lap of the season. Three men went into the Mexico City finale with a chance to win the title: the favourite was points leader Graham Hill (BRM), ahead of Surtees (Ferrari) and outsider Jim Clark (Lotus), all seen in this rare footage from the race.

Hill's hopes ended in retirement after a collision with Ferrari's Lorenzo Bandini, leaving Clark in the lead and on course for a miraculous win. It wasn't to be, however, as his Lotus started leaking oil and the engine seized on the last lap, with Clark eventually limping home in fifth position. Surtees, running in third place, was helped to the title by his team-mate Bandini, who let him through into second place, giving Surtees a one-point advantage over Hill in the final points standings.

2) Japanese grand prix, 1976

From the season when some grand prix cars boasted six wheels came one of the most enthralling battles ever or, as one commentator put it, "the racing grudge match of the decade". It was the somewhat familiar scenario of Ferrari against McLaren, with Niki 'the rat' Lauda pitted against James 'sex — the breakfast of champions' Hunt. Earlier in the year, Lauda had the edge over England's great playboy with a 23-point lead going into the German grand prix at the Nurburgring — but then suffered the horrific accident that left him close to death. In perhaps the greatest sporting comeback ever, he sat out just two races, returning to keep the points tally of Hunt — who was on a winning streak — in check.

It came down to the last round in Japan, with Lauda's advantage over Hunt just three points. On race day, the fog and rain rolled down from Mount Fuji to cloak the circuit and delay the start of the finale by an hour and a half. The grand prix went ahead, with Lauda starting from third behind Hunt, but Lauda almost immediately pulled into the pits — knowing full well that doing so was likely to hand Hunt the title — as the conditions were so dire. The remainder of the race was no breeze for Hunt, however, as he suffered a puncture and crossed the line in third place and, as you can tell from this fantastic clip, unconvinced he had won the title. He had — by a single point.

3) Australian grand prix, 1986

You can read the colourful report of the moment that millions of British fans cried into their cornflakes in this week's From the Vault, but, to summarise, Nigel Mansell needed to finish third in the season closer at Adelaide to win what would have been his first formula one title. He was lying in exactly this position when his left rear Goodyear tyre spectacularly exploded going down the back straight, sending his Williams FW11 bucking from side to side. He brought the machine under control and stopped at the side of the road before retreating to a caravan and the comfort of his wife. Alain Prost, his McLaren rival, won the race and the title in what was probably the most memorable grand prix of the 1980s and left us with a classic line from the BBC's commentator Murray Walker: "AND LOOK AT THAT!"

In this later interview with Walker, following his 1992 title, Mansell reveals that if he'd let the car slam into the wall they'd have ended the race at three-quarter distance and he would have been world champion.

4) Australian grand prix, 1994

Michael Schumacher's famous two-wheel moment was the culmination of formula one's most difficult season, which had been blighted by the death of Ayrton Senna at Imola. By the Adelaide finale just two men were left in the title race — Damon Hill and Schumacher, with a point separating the pair after Hill's incredible drive to victory in the wet at the penultimate Japanese grand prix. Schumacher was leading the deciding race when, with Hill on his tail, he ran wide off the track and clipped a wall. The Benetton, wobbling, rejoined and collided with the faster Williams as Hill attempted to take the inside line at the next corner. Schumacher was tipped on to two wheels and immediately retired, while Hill's race soon finished with suspension damage from the impact.

Given the season's events Williams did not challenge the result. Schumacher won the championship ... and Hill won BBC Sports Personality of the Year. This clip titled 'Injustice F1' highlights what many thought about the move — that it was an unsporting attempt by Schumacher to ensure he won the title. It has come to define him in the eyes of many formula one fans, and one suspects Hill has never forgiven the dastardly German.

5) European grand prix, 1997

Some would say that Schumacher got his comeuppance a few years later, while gunning for his first title with Ferrari, in the 17th grand prix of the year held at Jerez. Williams' upstart Jacques Villeneuve had almost won the title in his debut season the year before and was just a point behind Schumacher, having taken seven wins to the German's five. Schumacher was leading the race until Villeneuve began to overtake and, with his car's nose ahead going into a corner on the inside line, Schumacher drove straight into him. The Ferrari bounced off into the gravel and Schumacher furiously spun the wheels in a vain attempt to get going again. He couldn't.

Villeneuve's Williams survived the bash and went on to take third position and the title on points. The stewards were none too happy with Schumacher and he was disqualified from that year's drivers' title for his attempt to win the title by taking out the opposition (again). It would have been the Scuderia's first crown in 18 years; instead they had to wait until the year 2000, when the Red Baron bagged the first of a string of crowns without resorting to dirty tactics.

6) Brazilian grand prix, 2007

Alright, alright, it might seem a bit cruel to bring up last year's Hamilton-McLaren debacle, but there's no getting away from the fact that when it comes down to great formula one duels that were settled in the final race, this is one of them. Lewis Hamilton, in his debut grand prix season, was hoping to complete a fairytale story and win the title — and went into Interlagos with a four-point advantage. Fernando Alonso, his team-mate and, by now, arch-enemy, was second while Ferrari's Kimi Raikkonen was the outsider, seven points adrift of Hamilton.

The in-fighting that had so far failed to derail Hamilton's campaign came to a head almost immediately, as he was passed by Alonso and then ran wide and dropped down the order trying to regain the place. He could have recovered but, to the horror of the British tabloid editors and TV producers, he briefly slowed as a gearbox problem befell his car. After pressing every button on the steering wheel 36 times it soon righted itself, but by then it was too late. Felipe Massa allowed his team-mate Raikkonen to slip through into the lead, Alonso came third and Hamilton finished seventh. Unbelievably, the crown was Raikkonen's, with Alonso and Hamilton finishing joint second in the standings, a point behind. It'll be a different matter in this year's finale. We hope.

Who will mourn the passing of the old James Bond? Will Miss Moneypenny, now consigned to scraping a crust as a temp, speak up for those years of saucy winks and open-handed blows to the posterior? Will the ghosts of Bambi and Thumper emerge from their tombs to proclaim the wonders of a spot of slap, tickle and, ultimately, blam?

At the moment of writing, such activities would appear unlikely. The new Bond movie, Quantum of Solace goes to great lengths to impress upon viewers that, for Bond, the era of louche repartee, ubiquitous glamour and inappropriate touching is now over. In fact, it's almost as if the Broccoli contingent had polled a focus group of ardent Bondies, ascertained exactly what they loved about the character, then chopped it right out.

OK, so he keeps the dinner jacket. But he's at the opera when he's wearing it and, anyway, he kills someone to get it. And the martinis might be the same (they're not stirred at least), but it's a barman who's left to articulate the specifics, as Bond, well, he's just too shitfaced to speak. The general point, therefore, is this: everything you knew about Bond is wrong and if it hasn't been dropped, it will slyly be mocked.

The news of this development has disappointed many. Not me, though; not at all. Peter Bradshaw, for example, has already bemoaned the lost flirtation from the film. But I care not for a sophisticated Bond and certainly not for one who hankers after the finer things in life. I'd rather have a Bond who doesn't sleep than one who snoozes in well-appointed space capsules after "attempting re-entry".

Why? In the first instance, it makes for a more convincing action movie. It's that much-mentioned "Bourne effect" at work; Matt Damon's agent using his wits and his physique to turn over admittedly unending numbers of villains, where old Bond might have relied on a spring-powered poison pen. When you believe that the hero could actually be doing what the script suggests, the thrills become immediate, the tension more taut.

There's a class thing too, though. I don't want to reduce this to an archetype more suited to a doctorate from Fulchester University and, the truth is, Bond's role as a neo-colonialist and perennial misogynist doesn't really bother me. It's more to do with the fact that I have never aspired to owning seven flash cars, to grooming myself immaculately (check the byline pic, there's proof right there) or seducing a woman with a sly wink and the hollow promise of a life in the Cotswolds.

What's more, I doubt I'm alone in thinking like that. Not many people aspire to a life of loucheness. Russell Brand, maybe, but as we know he makes his own rules. A cool, arrogant charm is the preserve of bankers, barristers and, probably, professional sailors. And who wants their realm protected by someone like that?

It would seem to me that the keepers of the Bond flame have decided the same thing, and that whatever appeal a lethal playboy might once have had, that time has passed. If Bond has to be an Etonian (and legend dictates that he must), let him be an Etonian who seems awkward in his own skin, enjoys his martinis not for the glass but for the kick, and does his job solely because it has to be done. In other words: make mine Daniel Craig.

Helping a relative to commit suicide is like racing a child who is choking on peanuts to hospital at double the legal speed limit. This is the persuasive view of Baroness Finlay, the crossbench peer who was instrumental in defeating a bill to legalise assisted suicide in the House of Lords two years ago.

Baroness Finlay, who has a background in palliative care, says that just because there are circumstances where people understandably break the law, this doesn't mean the law should be changed. Or to put it another way, we need, she says, "laws with a stern face and a kind heart".

This is the rationale behind retaining the criminal offence of assisting suicide. No one wants to prosecute the recently bereaved who, in addition to enduring the incurable or terminal illness or a loved one, have sat beside them while they take their own life. Even prosecutors, whose instinct is understandably to take a critical view of breaking the law, baulk at the idea. They consistently decline to bring criminal proceedings in these cases, essentially interpreting the law in a compassionate way.

This line of thinking prevailed at the high court yesterday, as Debbie Purdy, the terminally ill MS sufferer, was defeated in her seemingly mundane request for guidelines clarifying prosecution policy. But Purdy's case is equally compelling. She says the previous tendencies of humane prosecutors are not enough. She wants certainty that her husband will be safe from the wrath of the criminal law. She would rather die alone than die without it. And if it really is the case that people in her husband's position will not be prosecuted, why not formalise this in public guidelines?

Purdy said yesterday that she felt judges had their hands tied, and she could not have been more accurate. The court went out of its way yesterday to express sympathy for her and her husband, who have accepted her death as a certainty and are simply trying to clarify their options.

But Purdy has encountered a constitutional brick wall. Unelected courts do their utmost to shy away from decisions that might create change where parliament has remained steadfast. They fear that allowing "guidelines" on assisted suicide may be a first step towards legalising it, something the House of Lords ensured did not happen just two years ago.
Baroness Finlay and others were instrumental in events then, when a 2005 private members bill to legalise assisted suicide was defeated. And, they insist, any new attempts to change the law will meet a similar response at the hands of the Lords. "I opposed the last bill and I and will oppose the next", said Lord Carlile, another anti-right to die peer.

But the real question is what the Commons will do. "A very significant body of public opinion" feels that the law should be changed, the high court said yesterday, giving permission to appeal despite its belief that there was no reasonable prospect of success.

"Some member of the elected Commons will have to have courage to take it on as private members Bill and drive through all its stages", Lord Carlile said yesterday. "The effect of this on the House of Lords of that might be quite powerful."

Not as powerful, it seems, as the effect this would have on those in Purdy's position, who said she "cannot understand how 37 years down the line from the Suicide Act no one has looked at changing the law more seriously".

If there's one thing all parties agree on however, it's that the law will be taken seriously now. "Only parliament can change it" said the court yesterday. How much harder do they need to hint?

The BBC has come under fire for allowing the live version of Top Gear to be staged at an exhibition with links to arms trade fairs.

Top Gear presenters Jeremy Clarkson, Richard Hammond and James May are appearing in the live version of Top Gear at Earl's Court in London from today at the MPH motor show, which is owned by Clarion Events.

The same company runs exhibitions such as Defence Systems and Equipment International, which showcases warships in London's docklands.

Campaigners against the arms trade have criticised the BBC's commercial division, BBC Worldwide, for allowing Top Gear to appear at the four-day MPH event.

"Clarion is already facing a backlash from their own exhibitors and customers over their ownership of arms fairs," said a spokesman for Campaign Against Arms Trade.

"Involvement with the arms trade is no longer an option for any company that cares about its reputation."

Under its deal with BBC Worldwide, Clarion is paying for the use of the show's brand and its three star presenters.

The Top Gear show is being promoted as a key part of the MPH show's appeal, and is being trailed at the top of the event's website, complete with pictures of the presenters.

"Once you've seen Top Gear Live, you'll want to spend the rest of your time at MPH with the 100s of exhibitors selling everything from the latest car gadgets to the coolest accessories," the MPH website promises.

Over the four days of the exhibition, the Top Gear team will present 10 live shows featuring "breathtaking stunts, amazing special effects and blockbusting driving sequences".

Any visitor wanting to see the Top Gear show has to pay at least £38 for entry, compared with £25 for an "exhibition-only" ticket.

Platinum ticket holders will take home a complimentary copy of The Big Book of Top Gear 2009, a hardback worth £12.99, as part of the £105 admission fee.

For BBC Worldwide, the Earl's Court shows are part of a worldwide tour designed to exploit one of the BBC's most popular programme brands.

The BBC is collaborating with Clarion on this week's show in London and at subsequent MPH events at the NEC Birmingham next month and then at the Coca-Cola Dome in Johannesburg in January.

BBC Worldwide defended its decision to participate in the MPH show. "We believe the MPH show is the best place for UK motoring fans to experience the exciting Top Gear Live theatre show first," a spokesman said.

"MPH is a hugely successful show which has been running for a number of years."

Clarion moved into the defence exhibition business earlier this year when it bought the DSEi, ITEC and LAAD shows from the publishing company Reed Elsevier.

Then in September it added the submarine exhibitions UDT Europe and UDT Asia Pacific to its portfolio.

Clarion's association with the defence industry has already proved controversial.

Earlier this month Bounty, the sponsors of Clarion's Baby Show, pulled out over the link, and Unicef stopped accepting donations from the event's ticket sales.

Clarion said its shows served only the legitimate defence and security industry, did not feature weapons for sale and complied with UK and international law.

The government has played down a report today that it plans to allow motorists to drive on the hard shoulder for a charge of 42p a mile.
The Department for Transport confirmed that this summer its officials visited Minnesota, which has pioneered so-called "Lexus lanes" where drivers pay variable charges to dodge jams.

But it said it had no immediate plans to pilot toll lanes here.

Yesterday the transport secretary, Geoff Hoon, announced the formation of a group to review extending the use of motorway hard shoulders.

Hoon said: "I have asked that the group focus on how to make best use of the existing key networks, for example, by the selective extension of rail electrification or the wider implementation of hard shoulder running on our motorways to provide additional capacity for motorists and to give them greater reliability and choice."

Today the Telegraph suggested the group would draw up plans to charge drivers up to 42p a mile to drive on the hard shoulder.

A transport department spokesman dismissed this as "speculative".

In a statement the department said: "We have made it clear that we are at a very early stage of looking at a range of options for managing demand on new motorway capacity, including tolled lanes and car sharing lanes. We would need new primary legislation before any tolled lanes could be introduced — even on a trial basis."

In July the government said it would consider opening up the hard shoulder to drivers during peak times on the M3 and M4 approaches to London, the M4 and M5 around Bristol, and the M3 and M27 around Southampton.

This followed a successful trial on the M42 near Birmingham.

The current financial crisis is symptomatic of a more fundamental disorder. The free market aristocrats locking their twelve pointers on the trading floor betray a peculiarly male volatility, of point scoring, dick-measuring ferocity.

Their behaviour derives from a testosterone surge that is reproducing a hyper-male culture of medieval intensity. The core issue is gender.

The Top Gear mentality of inflated masculinity is apparent on pitch, screen, and page; in the boxing ring, corridor, committee, front bench and boardroom.

It is on display in the brutalism of raunch culture with its lad mags and roasting.

It is celebrated by the predominance of diamond geezers, jack-the-lads, slacker dudes, dumbed down fatherhood, an infantilised version of true masculinity.

It is applauded by the moronic kindergarten blatherings of 'men' programmed into perpetual puerility by a revival of aggressive patriarchy.

Most shamefully, it is exposed by the increasing use of rape as a means of dominance in the home and on the battlefield.

In all these arenas, maleman struts his atavistic stuff.

There was a time when macho-masculinity was fit for purpose. Twelve thousand years ago, during and following the thaw, we needed action man, with 'a little less conversation please'.

As humanity struggled to survive a period of elemental chaos then establish order, structure and organisation, the soft fingers of social literacy were subordinate to the hard fist of physical control.

This is no longer the case. There is a new ethos, in which care has priority over enterprise, the housekeeper over the entrepreneur, stewardship over expansion.

EQ now outpoints IQ.

Technology has transformed the work place, replacing the masculine qualities of muscle, system, specialism and dictation with the feminine aptitudes of dexterity, multi-tasking and negotiation.

The emphasis within human organisation and business has moved from competition to collaboration, with a new emphasis on 'others'. This is seen in support systems, restorative justice, health and safety, and a therapy culture for victims, whether of trauma or disadvantage.

The new human narrative is creating an essentially feminine paradigm.

It is possible that the resurgence of masculinity is simply a cry of protest from a gender in decline, as it faces up to the redundancy of those qualities by which it has hitherto dominated the stage.

The current financial crisis serves to expose the masculine model as unfit for 21st century purpose.

Global management requires an economy of maintenance based on household need, not one of expansion driven by tribal greed. If the human vehicle is to reach a fourth millennium, then men need to take a back seat.

The media have seized with glee upon the plight of hedge fund managers who have lost billions by short-selling VW shares. knowledge and comprehension of the events at hand were sacrificed in favour of uncontrolled delight at the outcomes.

The drama surrounding VW's hyper-inflated share price should have been restricted to the market arena, rather than turned into a carnival freak-show act, with the losing hedge funds' traders playing the unwanted role of bearded ladies for the benefit of a mocking public. Of course, given the baying-for-blood atmosphere with which non-participants have been treating the City of late, that was never going to happen. Yet those who take such pleasure in the hedge funds' pain would do well to examine the root cause of their ill-intentioned joy.

The background to the VW affair is simple enough; what is less easy to comprehend is the kicking the press and public have meted out to the losing traders whilst they were down. Those caught short of VW shares were only doing their jobs; jobs that they had every right to pursue as a means to providing a living for themselves and their families.

But, as has been proved to be the case, because they belonged to the much-maligned minority of hedge fund managers – widely believed to be the root cause of all evil by arch-socialists, archbishops and politicians alike – they are treated as social pariahs, mocked and ridiculed at every turn, whether they make or lose money.

I first pointed out the volatility in VW stock six weeks ago, against the backdrop of Britain's witch-hunt against short-sellers; what looked awkward then for those short of VW shares turned into a nightmare of Biblical proportions this week. Thanks to Porsche's announcement that it now controls almost 75% of VW shares, and with a further 20% of the stock controlled by the State of Lower Saxony, little more than 5% of the equity remained in free-float on the exchanges.

With far more shares having been shorted than were available to be bought back by those wishing to cover their positions, the inevitable stampede for shares at any price meant VW stock could only go one way: and it did. Hitting an incredible level of over €1,000 per share, VW was briefly the biggest company by stock market value on Tuesday, eclipsing behemoths such as Wal-Mart and Exxon Mobil.

The combined losses suffered by several funds were estimated at being around €25bn, cueing thinly-veiled crowing in the next day's press. Porsche's release of a further 5% of the stock to help short-sellers satisfy their uncovered positions helped bring the price down to a more realistic level, but the devil isn't in the detail of the VW share price graph. The machinations of the market are, as always, best left to be devoured and digested by those who properly understand its intricacies and idiosyncracies, rather than served up to a poorly-informed public for their unsavoury enjoyment.

Putting hedge fund managers in stocks and hurling rotten produce at them is neither productive nor prudent; especially in these troubled times, when far greater links ought to be forged between those within and without the markets' perimeter. Making lewd, crude gestures at those suffering the effects of the indices' extreme volatility is embarrassingly asinine, not to mention unhelpful when it comes to picking up the pieces of the credit crisis.

The public's refusal to acknowledge that traders and fund managers have also suffered during this spell of market turmoil means the market players are unlikely to feel compelled to offer much sympathy to the public's plight in return, sympathy that many commentators are demanding be extended by the City on an almost-daily basis.

Hedge funds exist to satisfy the lust for lucre of investors, and it's not only shadowy oligarchs and the landed gentry who put money into them. Plenty of ordinary members of the public have an interest in hedge funds' performances too, through the investments of insurers and high street banks. Still, the minutiae do not matter in the short term; when the press want to pounce, with the public loudly cheering them on, all that's important is the great British tradition of sticking the boot in without a second thought.

The government was warned today not to "backslide" on taking measures to close the gender pay gap after a new poll showed widespread public support for tackling the issue.

Nine out of 10 of those questioned by the Fawcett Society campaign group and the Unison trade union said the government should do more to tackle the pay gap.

The Labour party's traditional advantage on equal pay was starting to slip, according to the report, with its lead over the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats on this issue falling over the past year.

Around two thirds said their voting choices at the next general election would be influenced by political action on equal pay.

According to the survey, 85% of men and 93% of women said the government needed to do more to ensure women were paid the same as men for doing jobs that required the same or similar levels of skill.

The Fawcett Society said the gender pay gap meant that women would in effect be working for free from now until the rest of the year, dubbing today "Women's No Pay Day".

Equal pay campaigners want Lord Mandelson, the business secretary, to include provisions in the new equality bill to make firms hold pay audits to expose any disparities between men and women's wages.

Katherine Rake, the Fawcett Society's director, said: "This poll sends a clear message to Peter Mandelson that any backtracking on equality commitments is going against popular thinking.

"In times of economic difficulty, voters want greater support for equal pay measures, not backsliding. After all, according to the government's own figures, unlocking women's economic potential could contribute up to an astonishing 2% of GDP.

"With the equality bill, Lord Mandelson has an opportunity to support measures that make financial sense during this economic downturn."

Bronwyn McKenna, a Unison official, said that equal pay laws were "complex, weak and ineffective" and needed to be updated.

"We know that women earn on average only 83p for every £1 earned by men, 60p in the case of women part-time workers. Yet only 126 women won equal-pay cases last year, enough to fit comfortably on to two double-decker buses. The legislation must be updated."

Harriet Harman, the minister for women and equality, challenged the pay-gap figure of 17% cited in the poll, as she insisted that the official figure had dropped to 12% since Labour came to power.

But she said that the government was "determined to do more" to narrow the gap through the equality bill.

Harman said: "We will ban 'secrecy clauses' which exist in a quarter of workplaces, and make public authorities report on gender pay.

"We will drive equality in the private sector through public procurement and we are working with business, unions and other to make the private sector more transparent on gender pay."

Uganda has lost 25bn Ugandan shillings ($12m) of Global Fund money due to concerns over poor accountability, according to reports this week.

The Global Fund has refused to release a second $10m instalment from the $36m pot it allocated for HIV/Aids activities in Uganda in 2003 because it was not satisfied with how initial payments have been spent, reported New Vision.

A further $2m is yet to be disbursed from the $24m allocated for malaria work under the Global Fund in 2004.

In 2005 Uganda was suspended from the Global Fund over irregularities in the administration of funds. This year, the Ugandan government began proceedings to prosecute those accused of embezzling Global Fund money, including two former health ministers.

Aidspan, the independent watchdog that monitors Global Fund activities worldwide, said Uganda failed to satisfy the fund that the arrangements put in place after its suspension were robust enough to protect its money from misuse.

In an interview with New Vision, an Aidspan representative said the $12m grants were now so far behind schedule that they "become irredeemable".

The news comes in the same week that the Uganda Aids Commission said Uganda requires an estimated 1.3tr Ugandan shillings ($700m) over the next 18 months to finance vital HIV/Aids activities.

The commission said that 25% of this sum should go towards prevention and 50% towards treatment, care and delivery of drugs and services.

This week has also seen groups representing people living with HIV and Aids reject Uganda's new draft HIV/Aids prevention and control bill 2008.

The draft bill criminalises the intentional transmission of HIV. The National Forum of People Living with HIV/Aids Networks in Uganda said that the country should avoid creating scenarios where people living with HIV/Aids are looked on as criminals.

Health system criticised

Uganda's decentralised health system is to blame for the poor delivery of health services across the country, according to health minister Stephen Mallinga.

Speaking at the 14th health sector joint review meeting in Kampala on Monday, Mallinga said the decentralised recruitment of health workers had led to a culture of "tribalism", with many health workers recruited and remaining within their own home regions, reported the Daily Monitor.

This has led to an uneven distribution of qualified health workers across the country, particularly in regions with few of its own qualified medical staff.
Mallinga added that decentralisation was also thwarting health workers' chances of being promoted and transferred to other regions.

"Once you are recruited to Kisoro you are likely to be tied up there forever without getting an opportunity to upgrade and be promoted," he said.

At the same meeting the Belgium ambassador to Uganda, Jan de Bruyne, warned that Uganda is off-track to meet the Millennium Development Goals on reducing child and maternal mortality as a consequence of its "poor healthcare system".

Economic troubles continue

Uganda's economic woes continued this week with an estimated 114bn Ugandan shillings ($54m) wiped off the local stock market in one day.

The losses recorded on October 27 were the result of panic selling by stockbrokers in the Uganda Securities Exchange, reported the Daily Monitor. Of the losses, Shs 23.6bn evaporated from six locally listed companies, including Uganda Clays, New Vision and the Bank of Baroda.

Despite assurances from the Bank of Uganda and the government that the economy would weather the global financial downturn with minimal effect, confidence among local investors is falling.

Last week the shilling collapsed against the dollar, falling to a low of Shs 2,200. As a result fuel prices have spiked, with a litre of petrol rising by nearly Shs 300.

With Uganda's heavy dependency on foreign imports, prices of other goods are expected to start rising soon.

The governor of the Bank of Uganda, Emmanuel Tumusiime Mutebile, attributed the scarcity of dollars to a fall in remittances from Ugandans working abroad who have lost their jobs or had their work hours cut.

No cut in aid to Africa

The global financial downturn will not see donors slash aid to Africa, according to the World Bank.

Despite the widespread belief that western countries hit by a faltering global economy will renege on aid commitments, Shanta Devarajan, the World Bank's chief economist for the Africa region, says that reduction in foreign aid among donor countries is still a long way off.

Writing on his World Bank blog last week, africacan.worldbank.org, he said: "Two things need to happen for the crisis to lead to a significant reduction in foreign aid. First, the financial crisis has to lead to a major recession in donor countries. Second, the recession leads to such fiscal constraints that foreign aid is cut."

He argued that the world is not yet at this stage of economic decline and that aid is motivated largely by non-economic factors.

His comments followed an appeal from the chairman of the African Union, the Tanzanian president Jakaya Kikwete, to the west not to cut aid to Africa.

Concerns have been also raised by Uganda's Central Bank that Uganda will face deep cuts in development funding as donor countries pour millions into shoring up faltering financial institutions.

This week some of the world's largest NGOs confirmed they were revising budgets, cutting staff and reviewing their 2009 programmes of funding and activity.

Robert Zachritz, World Vision's director of advocacy and government relations, told IRIN news he believed micro-credit programmes could be particularly hit.

"Much of this [micro-finance credit] relies on getting loans from banks, which is going to be a real challenge in the near future. Losing this credit is a huge problem for the world's poor, small-scale farmers."

Carbon finance for African farmers

Environmental experts are examining ways in which the billions of dollars available under the Kyoto Protocol could be used to help improve the lives of farmers across Africa.

Earlier this week, more than 100 experts from five continents met in the US to discuss ways in which carbon finance could be used to help fund agricultural development in some of the world's poorest countries.

Carbon finance has been developed under the Kyoto Protocol's Clean Development Mechanism (CDM), whereby industrialised nations can fulfil their commitments to reducing their carbon footprint by investing in emission-saving projects overseas.

To qualify for funding, agricultural projects in Africa would have to be able to scientifically prove how much they can reduce greenhouse gas emissions compared with traditional farming methods.

Issues debated at the meeting included the potential for new sustainable production intensification (SPI) technology that would reduce tilling of land, which releases CO2 trapped in the soil into the atmosphere.

According to news agency IRIN, systems under discussion include Conservation Agriculture, a method where seeds are drilled directly into the ground.

"This is a win-win-win opportunity," said Theodor Friedrich, an expert in SPI. "We have a chance to slow climate change, help poor farmers make a better living and improve soil health and productivity all at the same time."

He pointed out that developing non-tillage methods of farming would directly benefit small-hold farmers in Africa as soil that is rich in carbon is also more adaptable to the higher temperatures and increasingly erratic rainfall that are the expected outcomes of global climactic change.

One of the Pitts is said to have replied, when told he was ruining the country, that there was a lot of ruin in a country. So it is with the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland which, if one believes David Cameron, is broken, socially and economically, to which might be added constitutionally and politically as well if one goes along with the guidance paragraph for this article set out by Soundings: "The economic crisis has temporarily derailed the Conservatives. The New Labour project is exhausted and its electoral coalition has been breaking up. The political status quo has vanished and as the crisis unfolds conditions now exist for a new kind of social and democratic settlement." Well, yes, but perhaps not quite in the way Soundings might wish.

It is widely accepted that the 11 years of New Labour government have been essentially Thatcherism mark two. It will be followed, subsequent to a general election held sometime in the next 18 months and short of a military putsch by the Guards Brigade backed by the Daily Mail, by Thatcherism mark three. The possible variants to this succession (Conservatives by a good majority, Labour by a small one, a hung parliament inclining to Labour etc) will be of interest to political buffs but of precious little importance to anyone else, at least in England, as the policies of the two main parties will remain essentially identical – that is, a form of neoliberal economism philosophically and morally based upon Hayek. The only change will be a veneer of Keynes tilted towards state support of business. Election of the Conservatives will, probably, be followed by rapid moves towards Scottish independence, which would be regretfully accepted. A Labour administration would fight harder for the Union. Any variant will struggle. In the teeth of a vicious recession, with the national debt at huge levels and banks struggling to buy back government shareholdings, they will find it difficult to find policies to reduce unemployment and social deprivation. The main reason for this is that any form of Keynesian reflation will be severely limited by the appalling state of public finances and personal debt. There will be quite serious public disorder associated with this, probably with a racist element.

The result will be that around 2012, England (with Wales and, possibly, Northern Ireland being dragged along) will be ready for a genuine switch in national governance which will, most probably, take the form of a slide, possibly quite dramatically, into a form of authoritarian state-control, which might be called neo-fascism though its actual name will be something with "national" in its title. This could be accomplished with surprising ease – Britain is, after all, one of the few countries, perhaps the only democracy, whose national legislature can, quite legally, suspend elections for so long as it sees fit and which now has all the necessary trappings for a police state.

The only feasible alternative to this would be the formation of the grand coalition, which has for some years now hovered in the wings of the Westminster theatre. Just who plays the parts of Ramsay Mac and Baldwin is immaterial, the result would be the merging of most of the Labour and Conservatives in parliament plus some Lib Dems and the effective uniting of their parties outside it. Some form of rightwing party might well peel away from the Conservatives and, possibly, a remnant of the Labour left might negotiate with other left groups to begin the task of forming an electable party by, say, 2020. If, that is, England is then still holding elections.

Sorry, but that is about the best on offer. One possible alternative would be to distribute copies of the works of Trotsky to junior officers in the Guards Brigade on the grounds that it worked for Chavez. But it is a long shot. A woman in labour was among scores of people rescued today after heavy flooding caused road accidents and forced families to evacuate their homes in Devon.

Police, the coastguard and fire services were called in after fierce storms struck the county around midnight. Firefighters said the flooding was the worst they had seen for 25 years.

Flood warnings are in place across Devon and a section of the A30 dual carriageway was closed after junction 29.

The emergency services received more than 150 calls reporting flooding. An evacuation centre was set up at a hospital in Ottery St Mary.

A police spokesman said the pregnant woman began to give birth after a road accident. Many vehicles were trapped in floodwater, including a lorry.

"Due to heavy rainfall and freezing hail in east Devon certain areas have experienced serious flooding," he said.

"People are warned not to travel unless absolutely necessary to avoid driving into floodwaters."

The spokesman said no one was seriously injured during the night and coastguard 4x4 vehicles were being used to get to difficult places.

Susanne Reed of Devon fire control said: "It has been absolute chaos, it started just after midnight when we were out rescuing people stuck in their cars in floodwater. It got worse and worse and one crew got stuck in a six-foot hail drift."

A spokesman for the coastguard said the local authority was considering opening more evacuation centres when the number of people affected became clear.

There are flood warnings for the south Devon coast at Beesands, Torcross, Slapton, Torbay and Dawlish with high tide at 7am.

There are more flood warnings for east Devon in Ottery St Mary, Whimple, Talaton, Feniton, Newton Poppleford, Awliscombe, West Hill, Cadhay and Rockbeare.

Ottery St Mary resident Tony Fabry, whose wife Sharon is sub-post mistress in the town, said the post office sorting room was under six inches of water and a foot of water was flowing down the road.

The 46-year-old said people in remote farmhouses had been airlifted to safety and the RNLI was helping to evacuate some homes.

Other business were also under water, he said.

The treacherous weather conditions follow Tuesday night's snow around the country including the first October snow in London for more than 70 years.

It may have taken seven years for the Flaming Lips' first feature film, Christmas on Mars, to be released on DVD. But the band are busy making the wait worthwhile. According to a promotional video at the Flaming Lips website, "Mega Deluxe Editions" of Christmas on Mars come not only with DVD, CD, t-shirt, trading cards, bumper sticker and souvenir "ticket" - they also come with "real Flaming Lips popcorn" stuffed inside a "real" Flaming Lips popcorn box. Whereas some bands would just hire a Korean factory to manufacture pre-boxed popcorn, Coyne and his friends are committed to a home-made popcorn popping-and-stuffing process - while dressed in psychedelic costumes.

The Flaming Lips have been working since 2001 on their hallucinogenic sci-fi film, which debuted at music festivals this summer. Whereas the group is known for its splendid, joyous gigs, Coyne warned that the movie is not quite so jubilant - in fact, it's downright arty.

"When you go see a movie that cost $100m to make, that movie should always be good," Coyne told the LA Times. "For $100m it should never suck, even if you don't agree with it ... But I knew going into this we didn't know what we were doing. We were just doing whatever came to our minds, and so this could really just be dumb, boring arty bull."

Instead of the zinging pop with which the Lips now ply their trade, Christmas on Mars's soundtrack reflects the band's earlier, experimental days. "I wouldn't play this to an 18-year-old who wants to rock," Coyne said. "I wouldn't say, 'You got to check this out! It's deep and moving!' I understand this is strange, abstract, moody weirdness. But we would have felt really frustrated if we couldn't just go in every tangent we got obsessed with. If we weren't able to pursue this, we'd be an old bitter rock group, or at least more bitter than we are now."

The frontman has expressed the worry that, as an ageing rock-group, the Flaming Lips might get locked "into one groove". "Even Radiohead, as much as I like their last three or four records ... there's a colouring and a shade that they sound like, and which they'll probably move through time sounding like ... We never really wanted to be like that. We just keep finding new things we want to explore."

The Flaming Lips aren't planning to emulate Radiohead's business plan, either. The group's next album - which they hope to finish in time for a summer tour - is their last on contract for Warner Bros. Yet Coyne sees no need for them to set out on their own, as Radiohead did for In Rainbows. "I think we'd only leave because there's not a reason to stay," Coyne said. "Warner Bros really has believed in us ... If they restructure the way they deal with bands in the next couple years, I'm sure they'll be thinking of ways that will work for us and them. But our deal with Warner Bros isn't something we're waiting to get out of. We're not waiting to show them who's boss."

Besides, they're too busy making popcorn.

All religions can be cranked up for political purposes to be murderous and brutal towards the "other". Hinduism generally has a tolerant and non-militant image, but this has been punctured by cyclical violence against India's minorities be they Muslim, Christian or "untouchables", now known as dalits. Right now, fanatics sanctioned by the Vishwa Hindu Parishad (VHP) have been perpetrating violence against Christians in Orissa, east India. Approximately 60 people have been killed over a two month period.

Against this backdrop comes a moving and thoughtful film Firaaq, by Nandita Das, an established actor, social activist and first-time director. Shown at the London Film Festival, it focuses on the aftermath of violence in Gujarat in 2002 in which thousands were killed and many women raped. Through six vignettes which represent a cross-section of class, community and gender without ever appearing to be schematic, the film depicts the confusion, tension, prejudices, humanity and pain of a community trying to come to terms with the horror of what has happened.

This is an important film which should lend urgency to the debate that India is having about the lack of protection it provides to its religious minorities. The danger is that in an explosive and polarised situation, its message will not be heard or understood. Even in the polite atmosphere of London film festival audiences, the question and answer session betrayed the discomfort of those who identified as Hindus and tried to dismiss the film by saying that it lacked analysis, balance or that it was not political enough. This may have been code for the fact that the film had not referred to the "trigger" for the violence – the Godhra incident where a train full of Hindu activists was set alight. Two high-level inquiries into this incident came to diametrically opposite conclusions: one concluded that the fire was accidental and the second that it was arson.

The same debate is now raging over the violence in Orissa, which has been justified by VHP officials as a response to the alleged killing by Christians of a VHP leader, although the police say that the murder was carried out by Maoist insurgents. Whatever the truth may be, surely the triggering incident should be dealt with by the forces of law and order and not vigilante mobs being whipped into a frenzy by politicians.

Nandita Das wants the issues debated and the film to be seen as widely as possible. It is almost certain that Hindu nationalists will mobilise against it as they did when she played the role of an unhappy housewife engaged in a lesbian love affair with her sister-in-law in Deepa Mehta's film, Fire (1996) and members of the Shiv Sena in Mumbai vandalised cinemas saying that lesbianism does not exist in Hindu families. They said that they would have left the film alone if lesbianism had been depicted in a Muslim family.

How can art intervene in such a polarised situation? Can those stuck in a fanatical mindset be moved to condemnation of the treatment of India's minorities? One audience member felt that the truth of Firaaq would be dismissed because of who Nandita Das is – she would say that, wouldn't she? I would argue, however, that because it has been made by someone from a Hindu background, it is much harder to dismiss than if it had been made by a Muslim. Much as we who see ourselves as secular might hate to even reference our religious identities, they adopt a huge significance when the chasm is so wide and the need for a bridge so pressing.

Authorities and aid workers are scrambling to try and find survivors and help the thousands displaced after the earthquake in Pakistan yesterday.

As the death toll rose to 215, emergency workers scoured the rubble and mountain areas of impoverished Baluchistan province in south-west Pakistan, near the Afghan border. Reports are still coming in from the outlying areas of more people killed from the 6.5 magnitude quake, which demolished an estimated 2,000 homes in a string of villages.

The Red Cross said it was distributing 2,500 tents while a medical team with a tonne of supplies was helping overcrowded hospitals. Marco Succi, a Red Cross spokesman, said: "Overall we think the situation is under control, though there is urgent need for shelter and blankets because it is freezing up there."

Many people were too scared to sleep even in undamaged homes because of aftershocks, he said.

The US and Germany have offered to help but officials say they can cope without a big international aid effort.

News agencies said at least three hardline Islamic organisations were quick to help quake survivors. Among them was Jamaat-ud-Dawa, designated a terrorist group by the US government for links to Muslim separatists fighting in India's portion of the disputed Himalayan region of Kashmir.

The group set up relief camps and won friends among survivors when a bigger quake devastated Kashmir and northern Pakistan in October 2005, killing about 80,000 people and leaving hundreds of thousands homeless.

Yesterday, the army flew in supplies and medical teams into the hard-hit Ziarat district, where an estimated 15,000 people have been left homeless. Hospitals are treating dozens of seriously injured people.

Last night, officials said several thousand people slept in tents erected by the military. Soldiers were unable to reach all the surrounding regions before temperatures plunged to freezing.

Impatient crowds gathered in the hillside hamlet of Kawas as they awaited soldiers to distribute blankets, tents and jackets. Others slept in the open near the rubble of their mud and stone houses.

"We passed the night shivering and with the children crying. There were five of us wrapped in one blanket," said Ala Uddin, a 30-year-old farmer camped with about 15 relatives in an apple orchard.

The earthquake comes at an unstable time for Pakistan as the civilian government battle al-Qaida and Taliban attacks as well as a looming financial crisis.

Farewell David Tennant, and our grateful thanks for your sterling four years at the helm of the Tardis. We had such fun, didn't we? Perhaps you should consider handing over your sonic screwdriver to one of the following …

It is a shame that Tennant is leaving Doctor Who. The programme has been fantastic over the past four years, largely due to how he took the role by the scruff of the neck, incorporated aspects of his predecessors, but made it his own. What were your favourite Tennant moments?

Betting shop Paddy Power has a list of contenders to become the next doctor, which I only mention to discount it. It puts Paterson Joseph, who appeared as Roderick in the Doctor Who episodes Bad Wolf and Parting of the Ways, as favourite at 3-1 to become the first black Doctor Who.

But BBC Wales, which produces Doctor Who, has not even begun searching for a replacement.

The problem with such lists is that every utterance on this subject has usually been refracted through second-guessing what executive producer Russell T Davies thinks.

Thus Davies makes a favourable comment about Russell Tovey, who appeared in the play The History Boys and his role as Midshipman Frame in the Kylie Minogue Christmas special, Voyage of the Damned, and he is suddenly a contender.

In the end, it is really incoming executive producer Steven Moffat's decision. And he has barely said anything about anything.

Here is the beginnings of a list, which I hope you can continue.

Bill Nighy

Missed out when the role went to Christopher Eccleston. Was superb and somewhat doctorish as the newspaper editor in State of Play.

Stephen Fry

Would be hugely popular in the role. And talented enough to mould the part into something new. But would the ultimate renaissance man surrender 10 months of his life and his plethora of TV appearances for a single part? Eccleston found it gruelling and left after just one year.

Alexander Armstrong

At a loose end now that he has pulled out of hosting Countdown at the 11th hour. But the Doctor as a hooray henry?

James Nesbitt

The Cold Feet star has been connected with the role, even on the pages of MediaGuardian.co.uk, but it is hard to see fans warming to him.

Rupert Penry-Jones

His time in Spooks makes it clear that he would be an action man, but is he too pretty to play a Timelord?


Paul O'Grady

Jon Pertwee was a comic actor before he took the role, but he played the third Doctor completely straight. O'Grady would be an out there choice, but probably unaffordable. I don't know why the idea appeals to me.

Tom Baker left the programme in 1981, and he had a bit of fun at his press conference by wishing the next doctor luck "whomever he or she is". This leading to a frenzy of speculation that the next doctor could be a woman. Is now the right time?

Joanna Lumley

She was mentioned as a candidate to replace Baker but producers were never that serious about the idea and Peter Davison won the role. After her star turn in the 1999 Comic Relief special, the Curse of Fatal Death, written by Steven Moffat, the idea is even more attractive now.

Alex Kingston

Put in a sterling performance as Professor River Song in the Silence in the Library. And handing the role to someone who has previously appeared in the series has a precedent – sixth Doctor Colin Baker appeared as a guard in the series, even shooting his predecessor, the fifth Doctor.

Every actor in Britain would kill for the role. But the person who lands it may well surprise us.

In the centre of Belfast this Sunday there will be two parallel political struggles taking place on the street.

The first is the conflict between the city's republican community and the pro-British unionist one. The former are turning out in force to protest against a homecoming parade in honour of local troops who have served in British army regiments in Afghanistan and Iraq. The latter are expected to travel from all over Northern Ireland in defiance of those protests and demonstrate their support for the British soldiers.

Battle lines are drawn and the rhetoric between the two sides is becoming more bellicose by the day. Unionists such as the DUP leader and Northern Ireland first minister, Peter Robinson, have warned that the republican protests are a recipe for disaster.

Meanwhile Sinn Féin has urged the Ministry of Defence to call off the rally, which the party says will offend many nationalists and republicans opposed to the British army's presence in Northern Ireland.

What is at stake is the fragile coalition based at Stormont, which was already unstable due to Sinn Féin's refusal to allow a power-sharing executive meeting to sit since June. Moreover, the prospect of Sinn Féin's key demand, the devolution of policing and justice powers, being met – which would trigger an executive meeting – seems more remote than ever.

The row about a parade has soured relations not only between the DUP and Sinn Féin but within wider Northern Irish society. Old sectarian tensions and mistrust have bubbled up to the surface once more through the fissures caused by the row erupting over Sunday's march.

So why is Northern Ireland's political miracle threatening to unravel? The answer to that question lies in the second parallel struggle that will be played out this Sunday in central Belfast.

There will actually be three separate republican demonstrations at three different locations this Sunday.

Sinn Féin has organised the largest and the party has vowed that their protest will be silent and dignified. The party has abided by the law in the sense that it applied for permission from the Parades Commission (the body that oversees controversial public events) to hold its rally.

A second protest has been organised by "Eirigi", a relatively new republican pressure group comprised of many former disillusioned Sinn Féin members opposed to the party's participation in government with the DUP and its new support for policing. A third smaller demonstration will be staged by the Irish Republican Socialist party, the political wing of terror group the INLA.

The presence of two republican organisations who are against the current political compromise in Northern Ireland is evidence of why Sinn Féin had to gamble and hold its protest rally. One veteran republican dissident from Derry who spoke to the Guardian this week succinctly summed up the challenge posed to Sinn Féin:

The thing to watch are the numbers. This is a battle over numbers. If Eirigi brings a big crowd to their protest it will unnerve Sinn Féin.

In other words Sinn Féin is trying to hold that part of republican space that could be potentially occupied by its former radical, street-fighting element.

There is a lot at stake for Sinn Féin this weekend, though, besides trying to still appear edgy and revolutionary in order to fend off accusations of reformism and sell-out.

The party has captured a whole new constituency of aspirational, middle-class Catholic voters who are less turned on by the politics of street protest than their old base. A large proportion of this new Sinn Féin electorate will spend the Halloween weekend either behind closed doors in their semi-d's or travelling up to Donegal to holiday homes, hotels and B&Bs. Few if any of them will turn out to confront the British army and the thousands of unionists who will be out cheering them on.

Will a serious confrontation in the city centre alienate those new nationalist voters who want to see peace on the streets and power-sharing at Stormont?

At a macro level, the controversy over the welcome-home parade illuminates a wider dilemma for Sinn Féin about where it is going.

Out of power in Dublin and strategically outflanked by the DUP since the St Andrews agreement two years ago, the party might be tempted back to the strategy of tension, to use the threat of violent street protest to exact fresh concessions from the British government.

The trouble with this is that it risks provoking the very sectarian conflict Sinn Féin (alongside others, including working-class loyalists) has been successfully preventing in flashpoint areas all around Belfast in recent years.

On Sunday the numbers each protest gathers and the behaviour of them will be an important moment in post-peace process history.
