The London film festival comes to a close this evening with a showing of Danny Boyle's much-fancied new film Slumdog Millionaire, a drama about an 18-year-old orphan from Mumbai coming heart-stoppingly close to winning the big prize on the Indian version of Who Wants To Be A Millionaire?

For me, this has been an accessible, stimulating festival, richly and inventively programmed. The LFF is never easy for a working London-based critic, because there are all the regular releases to cover as well, but I think it is the best I can remember for a while. And this is because I consciously set out to find and (where I could) blog about some left-field films. I hoped for serendipitous discoveries and, as it were, news-bulletins from creative minds around the world.

El Cielo, la Tierra, y la Lluvia - or The Sky, the Earth and the Rain - by the 33-year-old Chilean film-maker José Luis Torres Leiva is a case in point. This fine film has another screening at the LFF tonight, and I would urge anyone with the time and the inclination to give it a try. It is the work of someone who unapologetically sees cinema as an art form, for whom the conventional certainties of drama and speech are subordinate to visual composition and the elusive mysteries of mood and feeling.

The film is about a lonely and melancholy young woman, Ana (Julieta Figueroa), who lives in a wild and remote area of south-central Chile. At home, she looks after her bedridden and all-but catatonic mother, and every day takes the mainland ferry to work in a drugstore. She appears to be in the habit of giving the wrong change, and there seems to be money missing from the till. Has she been stealing? Is it a cry for help? Many questions are left unanswered. Anyway, Ana soon needs a new job, and winds up working for Toro (Pablo Krögh). This tough, grizzled loner, whose existence has been introduced to the film in parallel with Ana's, roams restlessly about the landscape doing a little rough shooting.

The overwhelming impression of the film is one in which human character and human agency are not as important as the landscape: lush and sensual and fiercely, vividly present, by turns a dense and heavily wooded prospect and then a seeping, dripping wetland. It is as if human drama is the background for the natural world, rather than the other way around.

It is becoming a bit of a journalistic cliche to describe films as painterly, but I certainly think that this film is most rewarding if it is looked at in the way you might look at a painting, not waiting for dramatic revelations or resolutions, but simply responding to composition and mood. It can be exasperating to be told that a film places jigsaw pieces in front of us, and leaves it up to the viewer to decide where, or if, the picture adds up. But I think Torres Leiva's film doesn't ask that particularly: it just asks us to participate in the mystery, a mystery in which a human face can be as unreadable as the bark of a tree or the surface of a lake. An intriguing, and beautifully made film.

Laurent Nkunda, the renegade general whose offensive has created panic in the eastern Congolese town of Goma, portrays himself as the protector of ethnic Tutsis after the Rwandan genocide of 1994.

But to many Congolese he is nothing more than a warlord. The UN security council last night unanimously condemned Nkunda and demanded that his National Congress for the Defence of the People (CNDP) end its operations.

The 40-year-old Nkunda leads a small force of about 5,000 rebels, but they are well armed, well trained and have been more than a match for the government's undisciplined and poorly paid troops.

Nkunda, who has a penchant for sunglasses and crisp uniforms, has tried before to take Goma. The provincial capital of North Kivu province is a trade hub that sits near the crossroads of the Democratic Republic of the Congo,
Rwanda and Uganda.

His previous attacks were foiled by UN peacekeepers who used helicopters against his rebels. This time, Nkunda has spoken of "liberating" the entire country, although last night the rebels announced a "unilateral ceasefire" to avoid panic in Goma. The government in Kinshasa can only be too aware the region gave birth to the rebellion that overthrew the notorious dictator Mobutu Sese Seko in 1997.

Nkunda has been a soldier since 1993. Although he was born in Congo, he fought with the Rwandan Patriotic Front, the rebel movement formed by Rwandan Tutsi exiles that seized control of Rwanda in 1994, ending the genocide.

Afterwards, Nkunda, who has studied psychology, returned to Congo where in 1998 he became senior officer in the Rwandan-backed Rally for Congolese Democracy Goma (RCD-Goma), one of the main rebel groups fighting in Congo.

Congo's wars killed 5 million people. When they supposedly ended in 2003, the RCD joined the national army of the transitional government. Nkunda was made a general in 2004. But he refused to report to Kinshasa as part of the new integrated army and withdrew with hundreds of his former troops to the forests of Masisi in North Kivu.

In August 2005, Nkunda declared the Congolese government corrupt and incompetent and called for its overthrow. Nkunda maintains that his group exists to protect the Congolese Tutsi, known locally as Banyamulenge, from the Hutu remnants who fled to eastern Congo after the Rwandan genocide. Independent investigations say there have been some attacks on Banyamulenge but not to the extent the general claims.

Nkunda has clashed repeatedly with government forces. In September 2005 the Congolese government issued an international warrant for his arrest. He is blamed for war crimes and serious human rights abuses over the past three years. The Human Rights Watch group has documented summary executions, torture, and rape committed by soldiers under Nkunda's command.

Congolese officials have accused Rwanda of backing Nkunda in an attempt to turn eastern Congo into a buffer zone. Officials in Rwanda have denied this, though tensions along the border are building.

The countries have accused each other of cross-border attacks and there are fears the current tension could spark a wider war with Nkunda at its centre.

The history of photography is littered with salvage stories - of one photographer rescuing and preserving the archive of another. Probably the greatest of these is the story of Berenice Abbott, a young American portrait photographer living in Paris during the 1920s, an ex-student, like Lee Miller, of Man Ray. In 1925 she became friendly with an old French street photographer, who was a neighbour of Ray's in Montparnasse, and finally she asked if she could take his portrait. He agreed. She took the pictures, printed them - one front view, one side view - and took them to show him the results. But in that short time, she discovered, he had died. His archive had been left to a friend, André Calmettes, who sold off 2,000 prints almost immediately. Abbott decided to buy the rest. In the autumn of 1928 she took receipt of 1,500 glass-plate negatives and around 8,000 prints, and the following year, when she returned to New York, she took the archive with her. Forty years later it was bought by the Museum of Modern Art and thus the work of Eugène Atget, one of the greatest of all photographers, was saved.

Abbott was not a rich woman and for most of her career she struggled to make a living. To maintain the archive, she was forced to sell a share of it to the gallery owner, Julien Levy. Nevertheless, she had preserved, ordered and published Atget's pictures, while continuing her own work, almost up to her death in 1991 at the age of 93.

By the time her photographs were valued, she was in her 70s. She is most famous for a series of pictures that in their way link back to Atget's great project, the documenting of areas of "old Paris" that were being cleared to make way for the new city. But whereas Atget's pictures record the passing of places he loved, Abbott's project, Changing New York, was filled with the optimism of the post-Depression era when there were jobs again, particularly in construction: new skyscrapers, new cars, new roads, new bridges. There were jobs for artists, too, and the majority of Abbott's New York photographs were taken between 1935 and 1939 when she received funding from the Federal Art Project, the creative arm of Roosevelt's New Deal.

All this is described in a new two-volume edition of Abbott's photographs which, in the visual equivalent of remastering, have been scanned and digitally rendered by the printer and publisher Gerhard Steidl at the request of Ron Kurtz, an American industrialist and photography collector who bought Abbott's archive from her in 1985.
The volumes are divided by subject: the first contains her portraits, including the Paris portraits made in the 1920s; her pictures of what might be termed the "wider America", made on journeys across the country, sometimes on assignment, between 1935 and 1983; and her scientific pictures, many of which were made at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in the late 1950s and early 1960s. These are technical illustrations of different scientific phenomena: wave patterns, the strobe of a bouncing ball, the trajectory of a spinning wrench, the effect of light through a prism. They are reminiscent of Man Ray's "rayograms", photographs of simple objects against a black background, which he would move in the process to make a ghostly, abstract shape. Abbott's enthusiasm made the genre her own: in an age of technological advancement, photography, she believed, could be the "friendly interpreter" between science and the layman.

This first volume also includes an essay by Hank O'Neal, a photographer and music producer who first met Abbott in New York in 1972 and remained a friend until her death, and ends with a lecture Abbott gave at the Aspen Institute in 1951 in which she lays down her beliefs about photography. She dismisses pictorialism, the affected "painterly" photographic style that was popular in the early 20th century, and advocates straight photography, quoting Goethe to describes its greatest aim: to record "the truth of reality".
Volume two is devoted to Changing New York. It was a hugely ambitious and physically dangerous undertaking that needed a good deal of planning and organisation: how to find the right vantage point, how to gain access to a building, how to lug an enormous plate camera and the rest of her equipment up dozens of floors, how to calculate the wind resistance, the level of light, the depth of field, how to get the required grounds in focus. The importance of the correct vantage point was not only for distance but to accentuate the tight layering and juxtaposition of buildings in the city; to show the difference in tempo between the older, sedate, low-rise blocks with their generously spaced windows, railings, front steps and pedimented front doors and the skyscrapers rising up behind them, with narrow, tightly spaced windows in rapidly ascending rows, each row syncopated by the rhythm of blinds - open, half-open, tightly shut - or by the lights, on, off, all over the city as darkness fell.

One of her most famous pictures - so famous it has become almost a postcard cliche - is still breathtakingly beautiful within the context of this book. Nightview New York was taken from a window of the Empire State Building at 4.30pm in December 1932. It required a 15-minute exposure, and as Abbott comments, "I'm surprised the negative is as sharp as it is because these buildings do sway a bit." She had to get it right on the first try because by 5pm people would start going home and the lights would go out. It had been hard - as it often was - to get permission to work inside the building at all. "They always thought you wanted to commit suicide and superintendents were always tired, lazy and annoyed. They usually had to be bribed."

She photographed the city through the fabric of its construction: through high metal girders, from the bedrock of foundations, along the narrow "canyons" of Manhattan, cast into darkness by the shadows of a sunny day. She used the narrow gaps between the high-rise buildings as a funnel to direct the viewer's attention into the far distance where an iron bridge might be just visible in the mist. She was intoxicated by the city, by the upward motion of its growth, though this did not mean she avoided its poverty. She photographed in Brooklyn, in Harlem, on the Bowery and the Lower East Side. On a deserted street in Brooklyn, she found a black woman and her two children stranded on a patch of waste ground, as if their lives had been blasted by an atomic bomb. "When I set up my camera, no one paid any attention to me," Abbott said. "I still found it difficult to photograph scenes like this; poverty distresses me very much."

Like Batman, she was able to look down on Gotham from a great height. And what she saw was New York's enterprise: its advertising hoardings and neon signs, its cars, its gas stations, the elegant 1930s Greyhound terminal with the buses berthed along its sides like great liners at a quay. But she also found a place for the neighbourhoods where commerce still survived, as it did in Atget's Paris, at street level. Some pictures here, particularly her early studies of old low-rise New York, reveal the lovely detailing of residential blocks and storefronts, more reminiscent of the city she had just left behind than the one she was about to take on.

Abbott's black-and-white photographs are usually printed with strong contrast to emphasise the graphic way she uses the fabric of a building - girders, pillars, beams and fire escapes - to reflect the dynamic of its construction. These new digital scans lose none of that emphasis, but use it more subtly, with many more gradations of grey.

Everything about these books is in the best taste: good paper, binding, boards and a slipcase to protect them. They have been put together with the dedication of fans. The one sadness is that the text was not given a final proofing: the first volume has some misspelled names and typographical slips that, in a minor way, let the enterprise down.

Another, less dramatic, act of salvage was carried out in the 1980s by the actor Diane Keaton when she bought around 20,000 black-and-white negatives and a few colour transparencies from the estate of Bill Wood who, as proprietor of the Bill Wood Photo Co, between 1937 and 1970, recorded the ordinary people and pursuits of Fort Worth, Texas. Unlike Abbott, only 14 years his senior, Wood obliged almost anybody, or anything with a photograph: dogs, weddings, new houses, a rib-eye steak, a funeral parlour, legal evidence (why else would he have photographed the bruises on a woman's leg?), black children, nuns, Masonic brethren in full rig with aprons and pendants.
Bill Wood's Business is an edited selection of nearly 300 photographs from the archive, most dating from the 1950s and early 1960s. They present an eerie corollary to the Americans as seen by Robert Frank. Here, people look cheerful, communal, upright, proud; but they also look like cut-out figures in a cardboard landscape. As Keaton writes, when she first looked through the archive, "Everything looked ordinary, maybe too ordinary, more like odd, or funny, but not really funny, sort of flat." Behind their cheerful facades is the whiff of the America of Death of a Salesman and Revolutionary Road: that era of promise and disappointment.

Keaton eventually donated the archive to the International Centre of Photography in New York. This book, produced by ICP, includes an excellent essay by the curator and historian Marvin Heiferman and a bemused introduction by Diane Keaton. Once you get past the fun of them, the photographs, like the era, suggest something much darker going on underneath.

 Berenice Abbott, two volumes, is published by Steidl, £70.
 Bill Wood's Business by Diane Keaton and Marvin Heifermann is published by ICP/Steidl, £25.

Judges yesterday knocked back Debbie Purdy's application to the high court seeking to protect her husband from prosecution if he ever helped her on her final journey.

The judges were sympathetic, but said the law that makes assisted suicide illegal remains the law. Changing it had to be a matter for parliament, they told her. Yet politicians always shy away from this one – as the judges must know.

Purdy, 45, is has multiple sclerosis and has not yet made up her mind what to do, according to today's sensitive report of the court case by Afua Hirsch and Audrey Gillan in the Guardian.

But she knows that if her husband, Cuban violinist Omar Puente, helps her to die - and holds her hand, as she wishes - he risks 14 years in prison under the terms of the 1961 Suicide Act. He will go with her to the Dignitas clinic in Zurich, Switzerland, and take that risk if he has to, he has said.

Good for him. Except that the thought of her man going to jail for her is unbearable to Purdy in her distress. She wants the informal policy of turning a blind eye to such trips to be made official.

We can all see her point of view, though some argue that her campaign may backfire by making prosecutions more likely. An average of two such cases occur each year, usually painfully sad.

One hundred Britons have gone to die in Zurich - and needed help getting there - and no prosecutions have yet taken place.

I'm on Purdy's side here, and have made provisional arrangements for Mrs White to tip my wheelchair over Beachy Head in an "accident" after first attaching a piece of string to it. (I abhor waste. She may need it herself.)

Yet you do not have to have religious faith or subscribe to the traditional Christian view that individual life is God's gift - not something for us to destroy - to be troubled by the "slippery slope" argument which critics deploy against bills that would sanction assisted suicide.

A couple of years ago I attended a fringe meeting at the Lib Dem conference where Ludwig Minelli, the founder of the Dignitas clinic, was the star turn. Minelli called his service a "marvellous opportunity" and a woman whose mother chose to die that way gave a moving account of her death.

Yet Minelli's wish to extend the right to use his service to people suffering from manic depression struck me as a step too far. It focused attention on the core question: are patients competent to take these decisions?

Purdy clearly is, but the same is not true for everyone. When 23-year-old rugby player Daniel James, paralysed from the chest down in a sports accident, chose to end his life (not his first attempt) just 18 months after the disaster - in Switzerland in September - one wondered if the act was not premature. As they know in south Wales - the so-called Bridgend "epidemic" - young people are especially vulnerable. The James family's case is being studied by the CPS.

Yet many people, including injured soldiers, make new lives for themselves after a cruel period of readjustment. That, after all, is partly what the Paralympics are about. The Daily Mail reports a brilliant case today, that of paratrooper Ben Parkinson. His legs shattered by an Afghan mine, and short-changed by the army, the 23-year-old has decided to give to charity the £230,000 raised by Mail readers. Wow!

These issues have been much debated, not least in the House of Lords where Lord Joffe's bill to legalise assisted suicide has been blocked more than once. Critics say there is a rising curve of questionably motivated assisted suicides - ones where families are impatient to be rid of mum and get the will - in countries where the practice is legal.

Labour and Lib Dem policymakers talk about it, but back off from what is guaranteed political grief about a small, largely manageable problem.

Manageable? Newspapers routinely report that Dignitas, whose suicides are currently assisted on a grey industrial estate, is constantly on the move because neighbours don't like the regular trail of body bags so close to their homes.

I didn't warm to Minelli, who doesn't strike me as the warm type. But surely we can do better than this?

Parliament is due to sit for only 128 days next year – a post-war record low, Tory MP Sir George Young protested yesterday to Gordon Brown, who sounded complacent about it. A few extra days to establish a new consensus would be a useful investment of time.

There are signs that in the western world (including the US) religion is, indeed, beginning a long, slow – although accelerating – decline. All the statistics show that congregations are falling, mass attendance is diminishing and Christian knowledge is passing inexorably from our culture.
There have been two, or in some cases, three generations of people in this country who have had no connection with church at all. It plays no part in their life or their thinking. They are what I term "the religiously indifferent" – they couldn't care less whether religion is there or not, just so long as it doesn't interfere with their lives. Such people make up a vast and increasing swath of the population of Britain.

Why is this? In order to survive, a religion's mythology must be imbued into the next generation at an early age, before critical faculties that might prompt resistance develop. This is Richard Dawkins' meme theory. It is also the reason that most Church of England schools are primary schools and that madrassas start the process so early on in children's lives.
Evangelists know that it takes only three or four generations of unchurched people for the mythology to fall from consciousness, to disappear from the culture. People find that actually they can manage perfectly well without it. Religious leaders may despair about how difficult it is to reach "Generation Y" (roughly, 16-25 year olds), but if children have reached adolescence and they have not been infected with the religious meme, they will be mainly immune to it. The only way is to get gentle Jesus into their heads when they're four or five. In the developing world we are told that religion is strong and, apparently, unassailable. We see people in great crowds passionately defending their beliefs from insult, or walking round a giant stone in Mecca. But one needs to ask: do they really believe what they purport to believe? Or is the religious meme so strong in poor countries that it is inescapable? Does religion control so much of the culture that it is simply not possible to function as anything other than a religious adherent, whether sincere or not? I ask this because I've noticed recently how many people are telling me: "I'm not a religious person, but I am spiritual." This is rapidly followed by a defensive: "You don't have to go to church to believe in God." And this is what religious leaders should fear far more than the atheism or secularism they like to rail against. The spiritual-but-not-religious brigade represents a creeping disease that can eventually kill religion. It's a way of leaving the church without having the guilt of declaring yourself an atheist. The founder of the National Secular Society, Charles Bradlaugh, said: "No man sees a religion die". That may be so, but religions do eventually die. History is littered with their corpses. Until now they have always been replaced. But one day the human race's growing indifference to the gods will prove more lethal than any anti-clericalist dagger. Religion will die.
I am sorry I won't be around to see it.

But for a young woman, ideally red hot and blonde, who's been raped, tortured and murdered, there's little crime drama likes more than a dead child. A kid's corpse immediately raises the emotional stakes of even the most humdrum drama, imbuing it with a certain compelling nature it might otherwise lack. For example, Criminal Minds, which is perfectly adequate but still quite rubbish, recently featured a little girl abducted from a mall. As far as I recall, it transpired that her auntie did it, having discovered her husband was abusing the girl. Tonight's Silent Witness begins with the death of a schoolboy whose post-mortem reveals evidence of abuse. This initiates a race-against-time hunt for another missing child and the wheeling out of that other crime drama staple inextricably linked to dead children - killer paedophiles.

What is it about paedophiles and their activities that we find so, well, entertaining? Sinister child sex offenders feature frequently in everything from CSI through Prime Suspect to The Bill. And Special Victims' Unit is, of course, all about sex offences, many of them perpetrated against youngsters. (Doink doink!)

But what is the fascination with paedophilia? Is it that these "especially heinous" crimes are so beyond our ken that we watch to gain insight? Is it, as is the case with most detective dramas, that there's comfort in watching a disruption to the social order - particularly a disruption so appalling as the rape/murder/torture of a child - being rectified by the forces of good? Do we find solace in fictional restorations because neat closure is impossible in real life?

Or is it something darker that appeals about these dramas? As I might have mentioned, I watch a lot of Special Victims' Unit but I wonder what it is I especially like about it as opposed to, say, Criminal Intent or the original Law & Order. Is it a tabloid prurience that makes me want to watch stories of abuse and murder? Do we derive a thrill, not from the restoration of order - which sometimes isn't forthcoming in these dramas - but from its initial disruption? Do we watch to see the perps brought to justice or just to watch the perps?

Diego Velázquez - The Water Seller of Seville (1618-1622), The Drunkards or the Triumph of Bacchus (c1628), The Surrender at Breda (1630s), Count-Duke of Olivares on Horseback (1630s), Aesop (1630s), Francisco Lezcano (c 1630s), Calabazas (circa late 1630s), Rokeby Venus (Venus and Cupid) (c1640-1648), Sebastian de Morra (1640s), Villa Medici, Grotto-Loggia Facade (1649), Pope Innocent X (1649), Infanta Margarite (1650s), Philip IV (c1655), The Fable of Arachne (c1656), Las Meninas (1656)

The king and queen glow amid blackened canvases whose details are obscure. They alone, on the wall in the shadows at the back of the room, shine brightly. But their double portrait is not a painting; it is a mirror in which the royal couple are reflected as faithfully as doubtless they will be in the portrait the royal painter is working on. Diego Velázquez stands back from his tall canvas, whose painted side we cannot see, to look at the king and queen. The pretty little Infanta stands looking at her parents. A lady in waiting curtsies; a dwarf gazes seriously. At the back of the room, a door has opened and a minister looks in, sombrely. Bad news?

This is Velázquez's greatest work, Las Meninas, a dazzling allegory of the nature of art. He painted it at the end of a triumphant life. In his youth in Seville, he specialised in street people. His tremendous Water Seller is a study in human dignity with no honours or regalia of any kind: just the strength to endure poverty and isolation. Velázquez could paint, naturally, like Caravaggio.

Even after his early Seville scenes got him a job as a court painter, his first instinct was to paint robustly and demotically - in his picture The Drunkards a bunch of rustic boozers pose with the wine god Bacchus as if having their photograph taken with a celebrity. It's a painting whose ironic comedy and pathos have a lot in common with Cervantes's novel Don Quixote.

But Velázquez was too ambitious, brilliant and uneasy to stand still. He abandoned this style after looking at paintings by Titian and Rubens in the Spanish royal collection and travelling to Rome. His art absorbs the lessons of Titian's sumptuous courtly style, and he perfects a heightened, glamorous, scintillating painterly way with the sheen of silk, the creaminess of velvet, the ruffled flicker of lace. And yet, his perfecting of this high style does not tame his art. Far from it.

The Rokeby Venus is as sumptuous a demonstration of painterly style as anyone could wish for - the pale glowing flesh of the woman lying with her back to us is displayed, dramatically, on grey silk. But even as Velázquez invites the eye to contemplate her as if she were an expensive sculpture, we
catch sight of this woman's face in the mirror she's studying - and it is a real, imperfect face, serious, meditative. The blurred reflection makes the scene's luxury discontinuous, uneasy.

And in all Velázquez's great paintings there is the same grave questioning of things. Are the dwarfs he portrays supposed to be lesser mortals, comic figures? They have a sceptical toughness that make them the equal of kings and courtiers. In his battle scene The Surrender at Breda, generals meet courteously in the foreground - and a town burns in the distance. His portrait of Aesop depicts a man regarding us sceptically out of ancient, worn, unfooled eyes.

This training in sophisticated style and preservation of ironic detachment is all leading somewhere - to Las Meninas. In his only self-image, Velázquez here portrays himself in the act of making a painting - he sees himself through the eyes of the king and queen, just as they see themselves through his eyes. Reflections on reflections. Art is a mirror, but what it mirrors is a system of illusions. Life, as a Spanish dramatist of the age put it, is a dream. (Jonathan Jones)

Jan Vermeer - The Kitchen Maid (c1658), View of Houses in Delft: The Little Street (c1658), A Lady Writing (c1660), View of Delft (c1661), Woman Reading a Letter (c1662-1663), Girl with a Pearl Earring (c1665), Girl with a Red Hat (c1665-1666), The Art of Painting (c1665-1666)

Just look at the artistic epiphany of that brick wall. The sparkle as light catches that earthenware jug. The gloss of spit on the lips. That pearl earring. Forget the genre scenes and the allegories of this and that — Vermeer's paintings are a miracle of love at first seeing.

You catch sight of those bricks in The Little Street and they look as if they were painted today. They're that fresh. The marvel of this painting is not down to meanings. Or if meaning comes into it, it's more in the way that you might say a loved one means so much to you. Similarly, there's the stippling on the bread and the vertical dribble of milk from the jug in The Kitchen Maid, the downy scarlet blush of the hat emerging so seductively from the background shade of Girl with Red Hat. Here are intense perceptual insights embodied in the most sensitive of painterly touches.

Then there's Vermeer's remarkable compositions. The geometry of the headscarf acting as a pivot for the utterly compelling sideways glance of Girl with a Pearl Earring, the earring itself acting as exquisite counterweight. The pregnancy of Woman Reading a Letter is peaked by a downward gaze that stops exactly on the insubstantial scrap of paper that obviously bodes so much.

I wouldn't know how to begin to unravel the compositional tensions in The Art of Painting, and I'm not sure I want to. The baroque filigree of the chandelier, the muting weight of the parted curtain, that black-and-white chequered floor, the first tentative touches of paint on the otherwise blank canvas: it's all hypnotising. (Robert Clark)

Veronese - Feast in the House of Levi (1573)

The Inquisition had some tough questions to ask this great Venetian master about his version of the Last Supper in which partying nobles cavort around the central, almost dwarfed scene of Christ prophesying his betrayal and demise; there's a materialist love of people and stuff in Veronese that does indeed seem irreligious. He stood up to his interrogators and contemptuously sidestepped their accusations by simply renaming the picture as the less sensitive story of Christ attending the Feast in the House of Levi. (JJ)

Vietnamese (8th century) - Female figure from Huong Qua

The Champa dynasty was famed for its fantastical sculptures of gods, dancing celestials and gruesome beasts that were usually carved in sandstone. One of the last remaining figures is this sensual image of the female form. (Jessica Lack)

Vietnamese (9th century) - My Son Statue of Shiva from Dong Duong

The Champa kingdom, which ruled central Vietnam between the seventh and 19th centuries, is responsible for much of the country's exquisite architecture and sculpture, in particular the statues and reliefs of the My Son sanctuary and the monastery at Dong Duong, both in Quang Nam. The monastery complex was virtually destroyed during the Vietnam war; the sculptures that survived are characterised by their exaggerated features and worm-like decoration. (JL)

Elisabeth Vigée Lebrun - Self-Portrait in a Straw Hat (after 1782)

This friend of Marie Antoinette portrays herself as at once beautiful and talented; the straw hat is a sophisticated allusion to a celebrated picture by Rubens. (JJ)

Viking (c825) - Animal head from a Norse ship

Runic carvings entwine like gnomic tendrils around the head of a fearsome beast, perhaps a sea serpent, on this intensely evocative barbarian masterpiece that would have scared monks and peasants to their marrow when they saw it bearing down on them. (JJ)

Bill Viola - Five Angels for the Millennium (2001)

Five simultaneously projected images of a man slowly sinking through water. The most beguiling and ambitious of Viola's amniotic, baptismal allegories. After a while you begin to see your whole life flashing in front of you. (Alfred Hickling)

Edouard Vuillard - In Bed (1891)

A sleeper is dreamily submerged in a soft abstract world composed of stylised, flattened sheets in a muted, medical palette in this work, at once beguiling and worrying, by a rarefied Parisian modernist master. (JJ)

Creating a Real Time Strategy (RTS) game for consoles is no easy task, but EndWar manages it by streamlining options and enabling voice control. Battles are fought with straightforward commands - simply "who", "what" and "where" - while the move from top-down to third-person view allows for full immersion and accessibility. Highly addictive solo play is cemented with a Clancy story-line that follows the prelude to the third world war and beyond. But the game comes into its own with the massively multiplayer online Theatre of War. Battling against human opponents, territories are fought over in day-long encounters, with your performance affecting the following day's front line. EndWar's intuitive system works well, aside from the occasional voice recognition blip, and its fast-paced, action-fuelled gameplay will bring a new form of RTS to the console-loving masses.

I am writing this on Windows 7, the successor to Vista that was previewed at Microsoft's Professional Developer's Conference in Los Angeles earlier this week. Microsoft is keen to avoid a repetition of Vista's shambolic launch. Mike Nash, corporate vice-president, spoke at the press briefing about learning from the Vista experience, and the man in charge of Windows engineering, Steven Sinofsky, emphasised the rigour and discipline of the Windows 7 development process.

It appears to be working. Even in the preview handed out to the press, Windows 7 feels more polished and less annoying than its predecessor. The changes are not dramatic, but that is a good thing. Microsoft has left the core architecture untouched, so that software and devices that worked on Vista should still work.

Microsoft is also making Windows "quieter"; in other words, reducing the number of prompts that interrupt your work. For example, too many applications now install themselves in the Windows system tray and pop up frequent notifications. Windows 7 lets you hide them or turn off their messages, returning control to the user. You can also fine-tune User Account Control, the security feature which in Vista flashes the screen and shows a dialog whenever you change a system setting.

Windows 7 does have some user interface changes, the most obvious being a revised taskbar, which shows an icon for every running application. The Windows 7 taskbar has larger icons, full-screen application previews when you hover the mouse, and "jump lists": pop-up menus that control key features, such as starting or stopping a song in Windows Media Player, or visiting a favourite site in Internet Explorer. Application windows can be made transparent to see files on the desktop, and when you drag a window with the mouse, it snaps to screen borders: a small touch but one that feels natural.

Windows Explorer, the main tool for file management, has a new feature called libraries, which pulls together content from multiple locations and lets you treat them as one. For example, if you have some photos on an internal hard drive and others on an external drive, you can include both locations in one library and search it like a single folder. Applets like WordPad and Paint have been refreshed, and now sport fat ribbon toolbars like those introduced in Office 2007.

However, it will not be the new features that make or break Windows 7, but rather its quality, compatibility and performance. Windows 7 is less ambitious than Vista, its development is less rushed, and provided Microsoft can dissuade its partners from overlaying it with third-party add-ons of lesser quality, this release promises to be one users will actually enjoy.

The smartphone landscape is changing rapidly with the arrival of the T-Mobile G1, the first phone based on Google's Android software, and the huge success of Apple's iPhone business. And if both of these take big slices of the smartphone market, that leaves less for everybody else – unless they can find a way to respond.

Research In Motion (RIM) is already in motion: it has spent the past couple of years moving into the consumer market with hot new products such as the BlackBerry Bold and Storm. Nokia, the world's largest phonemaker, has targeted high-end users with the E71, N95 and N96 and similar phones. Nokia has also taken control of the Symbian smartphone operating system and is making that open source as well. Meanwhile, Microsoft has ... done not very much at all.

"We're very confident in our strategy, so I don't think we need a particular response," says Alex Reeve, who heads up the Windows Mobile business in the UK.

But while Microsoft sold 18m smartphone licences in the year to June, 2m short of its target, Apple says it sold 6.9m iPhones during the last quarter alone. As the iPhone goes global, it's not hard to see it outselling Microsoft's 50+ handset manufacturers combined. It's also not hard to see many of those 50+ handset manufacturers at least trying Android as well.

Microsoft is in a tricky position because, like Google, it doesn't make phones. It supplies an operating system that anyone can license, but ultimately it's reliant on partners who may have other ideas.

Taiwan's HTC, for example, has been a major manufacturer of Windows Mobile phones, but now it's making G1 Googlephones as well.

Windows Mobile can't even rely on its parent, Microsoft to give it a market advantage. Phones running Windows Mobile were the first to offer good synchronisation with Microsoft Exchange, which is the standard corporate email server, and this gave Windows Mobile an advantage in the business market. However, Microsoft has since licensed Exchange sync to rival handset-makers including Palm, Nokia and Apple.

Locked market

Reeve says: "We've taken the approach that we want as many people to have access to Exchange as possible. We have absolute confidence in our ability to sell our mobile product without locking people in."

Of course, Microsoft still has advantages for corporate use. Ken Dulaney at Gartner, the leading analyst covering handhelds and smartphones, points out that all the systems that were designed for warehouse and factory floor use run Windows Mobile. Also, companies can develop their own applications using Microsoft Visual Studio – which they already use to develop PC applications – and install those applications however they like.

"We'd never lock people in like the iPhone," says Reeve. "The whole point of a smartphone, in the Microsoft philosophy, is to make it open to applications, so everybody can build the solutions they really want."

Google's Android software is open-source (it's based on Linux) and free, so it could also challenge Microsoft as an open application platform. But Reeve doesn't think the G1 is a threat. "It has no integration at all with the enterprise," he says, and Google has a "kill switch" so it can erase software that you load on the device.

According to Dulaney, Microsoft had a choice with Windows Mobile 6: it could either "defend their enterprise turf against RIM", or focus on improving the user interface and attack the consumer market where the iPhone was making headway. "In either case, they were going to suffer," says Dulaney.

"I think they chose the right thing, which was to defend the enterprise area, where they're strong," he says.

Reeve, however, rejects the idea that Microsoft has been slipping in the consumer market. "We're growing very quickly in that area," he says.

He points to the HTC Diamond, HTC Touch HD, Samsung Omnia and the Xperia X1 – Sony Ericsson's first Windows Mobile phone – as being stylish designs with consumer appeal. A hit product can change everything, at least for a while.

Stylish hardware does not necessarily come with stylish software, of course, and Windows Mobile has come in for plenty of criticism. Dulaney says Microsoft has "different priorities – a passion for developers", but lacks Apple's passion for the user interface (UI). "They just don't have the genes," he says.

Face to face

The hardware suppliers and network operators can do something about that by changing the UI, as Palm has done, or by adding their own interface, as HTC did with TouchFLO. So far, however, nothing has come close to the iPhone.

Whether Microsoft will be able to do that with Windows Mobile 7 remains to be seen: Reeve says Microsoft isn't commenting.

But in the long run, the real question is whether Microsoft cares. If Windows Mobile sells 20m licences a year at a hypothetical $7 to $8 (£4.50 to £5) each, that's only $140m to $160m, which isn't as much as a decent Xbox 360 game. It's a very long way from the $4.6bn that Apple reckons the iPhone generated in the last quarter alone.

Still, Microsoft isn't likely to drop out of the mobile phone market, for two reasons. First, there's value in the way Windows Mobile fits into Microsoft's whole enterprise business, supporting Microsoft Office, Exchange and its Live web sites. Second, Windows Mobile isn't a standalone system, it's just one example of a software stack based on Windows CE, alongside PocketPC and Windows Automotive. CE has been used in thousands of products including set-top boxes, petrol pumps, jukeboxes and even sewing machines.

Given the scale of the investment in Windows CE, and Microsoft's ambitions in the consumer electronics area, Microsoft must surely keep it going.

What I think we are likely to see, under the Windows not Walls slogan, is Microsoft moving to a broader "platform play". Instead of focusing on particular products, Microsoft could present Windows as a more interoperable offering for the 2010s.

The platform will have three legs - Windows 7, Windows Mobile 7 and Windows Live - with Live Mesh rings automatically synchronising data as required across all your devices. (If you want to play with Live Mesh, sign up for the beta.)

Applications such as email, messaging and word processing will be available on all devices, and also online at Windows Live, with the two working together. You can take your pick about which you prefer at any given time, because they'll interoperate.

In the ring

It sounds like a good plan – but then, so did the Windows CE strategy in the early 1990s. However, even the best plans can fail if the execution isn't up to scratch, and sometimes things just don't work out the way anyone might expect.

For example, starting in the late 1990s, Microsoft has spent the thick end of a decade establishing its own mobile platform. It can't have imagined being overtaken by a late entrant such as Apple's iPhone. It surely couldn't have imagined being challenged by a phone from a search engine company, Google, that barely existed at the time.

Bill Gates met similar challenges in 1995 when he made Microsoft do a U-turn on the internet, performed with unexpected agility and speed. Whether Steve Ballmer can do it remains to be seen.

An early build of Windows 7 is now in the hands of thousands of software developers, who got the code at this week's Microsoft Professional Developers Conference in Los Angeles. Major hardware manufacturers already have copies, but many more will get them at WinHEC, the Windows Hardware Engineering Conference, which opens in Los Angeles in November 5.

Microsoft is providing tons of information, so I hope they're paying attention. Windows, uniquely, has to work on PCs from more than 10,000 companies, and run well over 1m applications for roughly a billion users. It has to handle everything from tiny handhelds to the large rack-based servers that run major corporations. Indeed, you can build you own PC and expect Windows to work on it.

It's no secret that too few suppliers paid attention to the last version, Windows Vista, which therefore got off to a bad start. Badly written software either didn't work correctly or kept bringing up pointless alerts from Vista's UAC (User Account Control) security feature. Some components and peripherals either had no drivers, or worse, had really bad drivers. Some PC manufacturers were slugging Vista systems with old crapware written for XP. Many other problems came from Microsoft's failure to deliver what had been expected – and when.

It took the best part of a year (and a lot of investment) to solve these problems, so that today, Vista SP1 is far better than the original – and far better than its reputation. To give just one example, the Windows Engineering blog points out that the number of applications and tasks that generate a UAC prompt fell from 775,312 at launch to 168,149 in August 2008, and the number is still falling.

Of course, changing Windows isn't like remodelling a boutique, it's more like redesigning a city. It involves moving well over 90% of the whole microcomputer industry, some of which is highly resistant to change. It takes time.

The good news about Windows 7 is that it maintains compatibility with Vista device drivers and software, according to John Curran, who heads the Windows Client Group at Microsoft UK. It will therefore benefit from Vista's problems in the same way that XP benefited from Windows 2000's.

What else it contains remains to be seen, because Microsoft has changed the way Windows 7 is built. With Vista, features were pretty much added through a "top down" process, which was uneven at best. With Windows 7, development is "bottom up", and teams are not allowed to add their feature to the main build until it has been both coded and tested. You may end up with fewer features, but the quality should be consistently higher.

Since builds are not "feature complete", it's hard to say what Windows 7 will include. We know that it will have a much improved UAC and better management of drivers and devices. We know it will have multi-touch features and gesture recognition. We know some parts will have ribbon interfaces: Windows is now being run by Steve Sinofsky, who was ultimately responsible for the ribbons in the hugely successful Office 2007.

Either way, it should do well. It doesn't matter if it's not a big upgrade on Vista, because 64-bit Windows 7 is a very big upgrade for the 80% of the market that is still using 32-bit Windows XP.

Ellie Scrivens, who has died aged 54 of a brain tumour, was professor of health policy at Keele University from 1993 until illness forced her retirement last summer. She contributed to both the understanding and practice of regulation in healthcare, in particular the quality of care. Her work was based on an encyclopedic knowledge of the "state of play" in systems for quality assurance across the world, and she was close to the heart of policymaking in England, Scotland and France, with connections in Australia and the US. Her advisory role also extended to the criminal justice system.

Ellie's work was often well ahead of its time. The real nature of regulation, for example, was elucidated ingeniously in her work. Health policy in the UK now emphasises external regulation rather than internal accountability for performance, and current moves in England towards official accreditation of health providers reflect arguments that Ellie had been making more than 10 years ago.

She was born in Solihull, West Midlands, and went to Malvern Hall school there. Her ancestors were Dutch but had stalled in Wales on their way to America. Her father was a chartered accountant who inherited a chain of newsagents in the southern suburbs of Birmingham. These two factors accounted for her aversion to mountains (or even small hills) and her propensity for buying chocolate bars by the boxload.

She was educated at Exeter University and the London School of Economics, where she took a PhD in social policy. This examined attitudes to cash grants with which individuals might buy their own social care; the debate about direct payments continues today. In 1979, she was appointed lecturer in social administration and health services research at London University, then from 1985 was lecturer in public sector management at the London Business School, and from 1991 was researcher, then senior researcher, in the health services development research unit at Bath University. She joined the centre for health planning and management at Keele as professor of health policy in 1993.

Ellie's research training had been first-class, and she was one of a small minority of social scientists at the time who could handle statistics (and computers). Later she found a form of policy analysis that was not only her own, but highly productive. She was a skilled and generous networker, but her scholarship was based on painstaking analysis, validation and synthesis, and often resulted in typologies that were both academically rigorous and useful for policy.

Her first book, Accreditation (1995), distilled insights from health service schemes overseas and asked whether accreditation protected the consumer. The theme of the service user, and whether consumerism or state control could better assure quality, was again central to her Quality, Risk and Control in Healthcare (2005). Who should set standards, and who should police them? Both of these books won the Baxter prize of the European Health Management Association.

In 1999 Ellie was commissioned to establish the NHS controls assurance support unit at Keele. Boards of all NHS organisations were required to sign off an explicit statement assuring control in a wide range of areas, for which the chief executive was the accountable officer. In 2004, when controls were replaced by wider standards, the unit became the healthcare standards unit. Ellie and her staff became expert in the definition of usable standards. Sitting between the department of health and the NHS, she brought realism as well as conceptual challenge and clarity to the development of standards as a regulatory tool of government.

Politically astute, Ellie noted wryly that she and her unit had outlived most of the NHS organisations she had worked with and for. She had a fuller grasp of the cyclical nature of policy systems than the civil servants who called her seeking advice. She was amused, as she worked on what was to be her final report from the unit, that the policy wheel had turned full circle and she was, again, advising on systems of organisational accreditation.

Her next book would have been an account of regulatory policy tools, but also of how policy actually emerges from government and the civil service. Her understanding of the importance of productive relationships between regulators and the regulated was based on her own involvement in local health services. She served continuously as a non-executive member on boards ranging from London health authorities in the 1980s, when she also served on the national board of Age Concern, to health authority, strategic health authority and primary care trust boards after her move to Staffordshire.

Ellie was a caring and generous colleague with an original mind, great energy and courage, and a gentle and sparky sense of humour. She took great pride in her family - her son and daughter Kester and Justine, and David, her long-term partner whom she married in the summer - all of whom survive her.

• Elizabeth Julia Scrivens, health policy researcher, born September 20 1954; died October 19 2008

A wave of synchronised suicide attacks on UN, diplomatic and government institutions in northern Somalia killed up to 31 people yesterday.

Three car bombs detonated in Hargeisa, the capital of the breakaway Somaliland region. Another two vehicles exploded in neighbouring Puntland which, like Somaliland, has been relatively peaceful compared to the rest of the country.

The careful coordination and nature of the attacks is unprecedented in Somalia, and marks a serious deterioration in an already dire security situation. Suspicion immediately fell on the radical Shabaab militia, which is part of much broader Islamist-led resistance fighting against the Somali government and occupying Ethiopian troops.

In Hargeisa, the Ethiopian consulate suffered the greatest damage, with up to 20 people reported dead. An attack on the president's palace killed at least three people, including the presidential secretary, while two workers died at the headquarters of the UN development programme.

"A vehicle forced its way into the compound and then exploded," said a UNPD spokesperson in Nairobi. "It appears that the driver of the car was still inside."

The suicide bombers, who were reported to have used four-wheel drive vehicles, struck within a few minutes of each other.

In Bossaso, Puntland's main city, explosive-laden cars detonated at separate interior ministry offices responsible for combating terrorism, killing six people. Dozens were injured in the five attacks.

"I fear that this is exactly what it looks like - the Shabaab," said a military expert on Somalia, who cannot be named because of his position. "We expected them to launch high-profile attacks, but this was extraordinary, requiring a large coordinated and concealed effort."

Analysts believe the timing of the bombings was no accident. Regional heads of state, including Somalia's president, Abdullahi Yusuf, were meeting yesterday in Nairobi to discuss the country's future. Peace efforts had received a boost over the weekend when Yusuf's government and the opposition Alliance for the Re-liberation of Somalia (ARS) signed a deal in Djibouti agreeing to a ceasefire, and a phased withdrawal of Ethiopian troops.

But a breakaway wing of the ARS, as well as the Shabaab, rejected the deal. They refuse to enter negotiations before the complete withdrawal of the Ethiopian forces that invaded Somalia in December 2006 to oust an Islamist authority from power.

Previously during peace negotiations the Shabaab has launched large attacks, mainly in Mogadishu, to demonstrate that they have control on the ground.

"It's clear that the Shabaab, or jihadis or whatever you want to call them, are trying to make a statement that they target any place in Somalia, not just the south," said a western diplomat in Nairobi. "But we cannot let this undermine the Djibouti agreement, and we have to accept that these sort of attacks may continue in the short term."

Previously there have only been one or two small suicide attacks in Somalia.

Vodafone is understood to have clinched a strategic partnership with Mobile TeleSystems, the largest mobile phone operator in Russia, as it searches for growth in emerging markets.

The deal, which Moscow-based MTS is expected to announce this morning, will see Vodafone sign up MTS as a "partner network" to bring a range of Vodafone services into Russia and other countries including Ukraine and Belarus.

MTS and its subsidiaries have more than 87 million customers in Russia, Armenia, Belarus, Turkmenistan, Ukraine and Uzbekistan, out of a total population of more than 230 million.

MTS has been listed in New York for the past eight years and is majority-owned by billionaire Vladimir Yevtushenkov's Sistema conglomerate. Vodafone is not expected to take an equity stake in the firm. Neither Vodafone nor MTS would comment on the move.

The deal will provide reassurance for western companies who have become concerned about doing business in Russia after the political interference that forced BP into a major restructuring of its BP-TNK joint venture and the Kremlin's incursion into Georgia.

In July, Vodafone admitted that some of its core markets such as Spain and the UK were becoming challenging because of the worsening economic climate. The company will announce its half-year results on November 11 and the management is expected to deliver a gloomy prognosis for Vodafone's core European businesses and to announce another round of cost cuts.

To try to make up the slack, the company recently restructured its management to focus on emerging markets. It has already made acquisitions in India, Turkey and Ghana and recently strengthened its position in South Africa by acquiring control of the country's largest cellular phone operator, Vodacom.

Yesterday, Vodafone announced plans to increase its stake in Poland's telecoms operator Polkomtel by 4.8% to 24.4%, for €176m (£140m).

It has also made extensive use of partnerships. It has more than 40 network partners across the world and has used them to expand eastwards in Europe. It has partner networks in Slovenia, Croatia, Macedonia, Serbia, Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia. Under the terms of these agreements, Vodafone and its partners cooperate in the development of global services under dual brand logos. Services in Russia are expected to be marketed under the MTS-Vodafone logo.

Welcome, my friends, to the New Optimism: stockmarkets surging, VW shares up 400%, ivory markets booming, and it's even snowing. It hasn't snowed in south-east England in October since the mid-70s! Could this be a sign heralding an unprecedented Winter of Content? Is it too early to pretend we've turned the corner?

In terms of uplifting animal news, there has rarely been a tale as heartwarming as that of Carla the angelfish, who lived happily at the London Aquarium for 10 years before developing a life-threatening hernia, which had recently begun to squeeze her organs right out of her. But after a £500, 30-minute operation performed by vet Sue Thornton, Carla's organs are back inside and she's reportedly doing fine. In more ruthless times it might have been hard to justify taking a fish out of water and putting it under the knife unless you were planning to gut it, but there's no doubt that when market confidence takes a knock, a little sentimentality goes a long way. Yes, there may yet come a time when we have to eat all the fish in the London Aquarium, but Carla's story shows us that we're not there yet.

It is quite possible that from here on in things can only get better but, at this delicate stage, negative thinking is more dangerous then negative equity. So stop fearing fear itself and keep your eye on those upward-trending market indices. Don't look at home repossession rates or sterling, by the way. Just sit back and dream about what we're going to do with Jonathan Ross's salary.

Recession-busting tip: Many of autumn's best-loved decorative vegetables are edible, including most types of squash. Before you throw away that harvest display, check the internet for far-out recipe ideas. Be careful though - certain squashes are poisonous, particularly plastic ones.

What's going cheap right now: Plastic luggage, inflatable swimming pools, bricks, mortar.

So Jonathan Ross (I'm worth 1,000 BBC journalists) is suspended and Russell Brand has resigned. MPs condemn them in the Commons: "base", "vulgar", "puerile", "predictable", they say - while on these pages Jack Straw, the justice secretary, joins in, labelling the pair "so-called stars". And the reaction from the BBC's cash-strapped newsroom is instantaneous. "It's the most entertainment we have had from them all year," a staffer tells us. So the effort wasn't wasted.

• Straw has also been plagued by bleeding hearts among the criminal justice lobby using impenetrable language. Last week he complained that phrases such as the "criminogenic needs of offenders" send him "nuts", and one must guess that the madness started in 1998, when he himself hailed Home Office research "designed to assess the specific criminogenic factors associated with offending by women." If the justice secretary can move on from that sort of language, why can't everyone else?

• Further and better reaches us about events at Yarl's Wood detention centre, where staff found that asylum seekers deprived of a pamphlet explaining how to construct appeals were, as a direct result, less able to mount those appeals. Yarl's Wood we know; but it's still not right. Last week we reported that officials were made to hand the pamphlets back following complaints to the UK Border Agency, and now we have an update. Of the two women so deprived, one has since been released; the other's deportation has been postponed. And it is the latter case we turn to again today, for it transpires that officials were seeking to send her back to Kenya, even though she was on suicide watch - having already made one attempt to take her life in Yarl's Wood. When London MEP Jean Lambert made representations on her behalf to the Border Agency, it was forced to admit it did not know the detainee had tried to kill herself with an overdose. Yarl's Wood simply had not told the agency. Ministers promise a system that is fast and fair, but it is obviously a work in progress. One out of two is not bad.

• After many weeks in the eye of the storm, it should have been comforting for the National Black Police Association to escape to the sanctuary of its annual conference in York. Criticism has been unremitting since the NBPA said it would discourage black recruits. No surprise they sought to take stock among friends. And that might have been the case had they invited, as they intended, the robust but undeniably sophisticated David Davis MP, former shadow home secretary. Alas, the speaking invite went to his scratchier Tory colleague, David Davies, MP for Monmouth - who, once there, lambasted the NBPA for being racist. What to do? Davis; Davies. They all look the same.

• But then they grow accustomed to the scandals and the subsequent apologies. Whoops, there goes another one. This time in Northern Ireland. "There were no overweight people in Auschwitz," said Angie Best - former wife of George - during a BBC TV discussion about obesity. "It was a slip of the tongue," says Angie, now chastened. At least her idiocy was live.

• So did you hear the one where Gordon had to introduce Nelson to Amy Winehouse because the old boy had never heard of the hapless songstress? How, required to sing Free Nelson Mandela, she actually sang "Blakey My Fella". Many thousands will have heard it by now because the tale has become the stock joke for occasions addressed by the prime minister. He told it to the TUC in Brighton last month, and at the Foreign Office on October 8 at a ceremony for Britain's 100 most influential black people; he told it again in Downing Street on October 20, at a reception for activists involved in the anti-knife/gun campaign, the Peace Alliance; and yesterday we learned that at a recent lunch attended by the actor Julian Rhind-Tutt, he gave it another airing. The PM has learned, we are told, that he is best when he is bold; and with that in mind, might this not be a good time for us - and that means all of us - to find a new joke for Gordon. Think not of what he has done for us. We must do what we can for him.

Cristiano Ronaldo began another hugely satisfying evening's work by collecting the Golden Boot for his 42 goals last season and, after another fine demonstration of the art of scoring, it ended with his name being sung with more vigour than any other time since his summer dalliance with Real Madrid. There will always be some Manchester United supporters who struggle to forgive and forget but for as long as Ronaldo can strike this kind of fear in opposition defences he will inevitably succeed in winning over the majority.

Another two goals were served up here and if the Portuguese had not aimed his shot too close to Robert Green in the 89th minute Europe's most prolific scorer would have added another souvenir match ball to his collection. As it was, his goals had already settled the game on a night that will otherwise be remembered for West Ham's feeble resistance and the sheer brilliance with which Dimitar Berbatov, an Old Trafford hero in the making, set up the second goal.

The biggest compliment that can be paid to Berbatov is that, even in a stadium with the rich nostalgia and sepia-tinted memories of Old Trafford, it was difficult to remember a more sublime piece of penalty-area skill - even from Ronaldo. Sir Alex Ferguson used such adjectives as "stunning" and "magnificent" and nobody at Old Trafford will ever tire of seeing the television replays of how Berbatov deceived his marker, James Collins, to leave Ronaldo with an open goal.

Yet Ferguson was not altogether happy. Two up after half an hour, a thrashing might easily have materialised but, to the manager's irritation, his team eased off in the second half, despite playing the last 21 minutes with Ronaldo, Berbatov, Carlos Tevez and Wayne Rooney - a substitute - all on the pitch.

"The first half was magnificent and after that I was looking forward to more of the same," said Ferguson. "I was hoping they could add to their goals tally because that could be important at the end of the season. But they took their foot off the pedal and played at a couple of gears below what they are capable of. They ended up too lax for me."

The reason for that, perhaps, was that West Ham were so feeble that the players in red became bored with their own superiority. Ronaldo's first goal, for example, came in the midst of one of those extended spells when every West Ham player must have been enveloped by a deep sense of foreboding. Nani played the ball across the penalty area and Ronaldo was on to it in a flash, lashing a left-foot shot into the corner of Green's net. How would he celebrate? Old Trafford's amateur psychologists waited to analyse his body language and, after a dramatic pause of which Robert de Niro would have been proud, there was an explosion of unrestrained joy. Point made.

That was in the 14th minute and, from that moment onwards, Gianfranco Zola must have been hoping the final whistle could somehow be brought forward. The Italian won his first two league games after taking over from Alan Curbishley as manager but since then West Ham's form has plummeted. They also lost Valon Behrami to a potentially serious injury and their fourth consecutive defeat was all but confirmed when Berbatov's brilliance set up Ronaldo again.

The Bulgarian had done well even to keep Anderson's through-ball in play, reaching it only a few inches before it went out for a goal kick, but it was what came next which took the breath away. In one sublime movement Berbatov spun, pirouetted and danced away from Collins. The defender was still coming to his senses as Berbatov advanced towards goal and slid a beautifully weighted pass across the six-yard area. Ronaldo, alert as always, got there first, leaving Ferguson to eulogise about his £30.5m new signing.

"I'm going to have to see it again to understand how he [Berbatov] did it," the United manager said. "You'd pay double the money to watch that - fantastic imagination, control and balance."

Ferguson had made five changes from the team that drew 1-1 against Everton on Saturday, with Edwin van der Sar given the night off on his 38th birthday. His replacement, Tomasz Kuszczak, can be a danger to his own team sometimes but it was a measure of West Ham's performance that they did not force the Pole into a save until the final few minutes. This was as one-sided as they come.

Gene Upshaw was not only a Hall of Fame American football player, but arguably that country's most successful trade union leader of the last quarter of a century. The skills that made him a great lineman in the National Football League (NFL) - the strength to move an opponent in the direction he wanted, the flexibility to chase down a blocking target, and the tenacity to hold his ground protecting his quarterback - served him in his second career as executive director of the NFL's players' association.

Upshaw, who has died aged 63 at his home in Lake Tahoe, Nevada, only days after being diagnosed with pancreatic cancer, took over leadership of the union in 1983 at a time of crisis. He brought his members to new heights of reward and contractual freedom, while cooperating with the league to maintain its competitive balance. In the modern era of salary caps and free agency, the NFL model serves as an example for sports worldwide, not least English football.

NFL players receive 60% of the league's gross revenues within a salary cap of $116m between each team's 53-man roster. Although contracts are not guaranteed, players collect bonus money up front, in effect replacing lost salary if the team releases them. But the team owners announced recently that they would opt out of the current deal, which expires in 2010, and Upshaw was also under pressure from his members, some of whom wanted guaranteed contracts like the other major American sports, or a more aggressive stance against the cap. They felt he was not doing enough for former players who had fallen on hard times.

Upshaw was born in Robstown, Texas. High school was disrupted because he picked cotton to assist the family finances, and he played only one year of high school football. But during his studies at the traditionally black Texas College of Arts and Industries, the Oakland Raiders owner Al Davis overruled his scouts and chose Upshaw with his first pick in the college draft, installing him at left guard. Upshaw was named to all-star teams 11 times in his 15-year career and played in three Super Bowls across three decades, winning twice, in 1976 and 1980. He was a leader on and off the field, becoming his team's union representative, then a member of the player association's executive board. After retiring in 1981, he became its president.

The following year the executive director of the players' association, Ed Garvey, demanded 55% of gross revenues in salaries. The owners' attitude was personified by Hugh Culverhouse, of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, who growled: "Don't give that damn communist a thing." Ironically, the owners owed their success to being forced by the then commissioner Pete Rozelle to share all national television revenue equally. Union members, already divided by the terms of a proposed deal, were further split by Garvey's strike call. Upshaw stood by Garvey but the strike cost them two months of the 1982 season, and Garvey was subsequently replaced by Upshaw. He was helped by having won the right for players to see all contracts. When they discovered what their team-mates were earning, Upshaw's calls for greater unity were heeded.

When the deal expired in 1987, the owners were better prepared. The Dallas Cowboys president Tex Schramm told Upshaw: "You guys are the cattle and we're the ranchers. We can always get more cattle." When the players went on strike again, the owners assembled scab teams of replacement players to stage an ersatz season. The issue led to legal action under anti-trust legislation, and although a deal was struck in 1989, it took four more years for the details to be hammered out.

I met Upshaw, a strong supporter of NFL Europe, a number of times. He once explained that the owners failed to realise that the salary cap protected them, not from the players, but from themselves, since rich teams would always pay over the odds, and small teams would have to match their scale. He was proved right.

As a player, Upshaw had been known for wrapping his fists in tape until they resembled clubs. But as his successor Paul Tagliabue pointed out: "If you hit him on the head, he could strike back twice as hard, but he didn't always... He never lost sight of the big picture."

Upshaw is survived by his wife, Terri, and three sons.
